Most Important Books to Read

Alex Brunk

2022-10-26

Most Important Books

I am an avid reader, and have been since I was a small child. My interests include historical fiction, fantasy/sci-fi, biographies, histories, and works of political philosophy.

In the last few years however, Ive been attempting to read more books that are considered classics. There is no universal definition of what is a classic though there are many good lists such as the Great Books of the Western World prepared by the late great Mortimer Adler.

A few examples of classics Ive read in the last few years are:

  • Meditations by Marcus Aurelius
  • The Power and the Glory by Graham Greene
  • All Quiet on the Western Front by Erich Maria Remarque
  • The Stranger by Albert Camus
  • Utopia by Thomas More
  • The Rights of Man by Thomas Paine
  • Moby Dick by Herman Melville
  • Brave New World by Aldous Huxley
  • Narrative of Life of Frederick Douglass by Frederick Douglass
  • The Time Machine by HG Wells
  • Heart of Darkness by Joseph Conrad

These are all books that show up on various lists of classics from different eras and genres. But any such decisions are arbitrary. Who decides what a classic is? How should one determine which are worth reading? How to make decisions about which books to read given finite time to read them?

The Concept - A Model to Determine the Importance of Classics

I turned to Project Gutenberg, which has an extensive library of public domain books. There is an existing Python library called gutenbergpy that has been designed to make it easier to download Project Gutenberg texts into Python code.

As an example, here is a full printing of Moby Dick without header information using the package instructions available here: https://github.com/raduangelescu/gutenbergpy and the unique identifier for the Moby Dick text found by googling here https://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/15

import gutenbergpy.textget
# return Moby Dick text using Project Gutenberg ID
moby_dick = gutenbergpy.textget.get_text_by_id(15)
# print(moby_dick)
# Strip headers from text
clean_moby_dick = gutenbergpy.textget.strip_headers(moby_dick)
print(clean_moby_dick)
## b'\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nMoby-Dick\r\n\r\nor,\r\n\r\nTHE WHALE.\r\n\r\nby Herman Melville\r\n\r\n\r\nContents\r\n\r\n Etymology\r\n Extracts\r\n\r\n CHAPTER I.\xe2\x80\x94Loomings\r\n CHAPTER II.\xe2\x80\x94The Carpet Bag\r\n CHAPTER III.\xe2\x80\x94The Spouter-Inn\r\n CHAPTER IV.\xe2\x80\x94The Counterpane\r\n CHAPTER V.\xe2\x80\x94Breakfast\r\n CHAPTER VI.\xe2\x80\x94The Street\r\n CHAPTER VII.\xe2\x80\x94The Chapel\r\n CHAPTER VIII.\xe2\x80\x94The Pulpit\r\n CHAPTER IX.\xe2\x80\x94The Sermon\r\n CHAPTER X.\xe2\x80\x94A Bosom Friend\r\n CHAPTER XI.\xe2\x80\x94Nightgown\r\n CHAPTER XII.\xe2\x80\x94Biographical\r\n CHAPTER XIII.\xe2\x80\x94Wheelbarrow\r\n CHAPTER XIV.\xe2\x80\x94Nantucket\r\n CHAPTER XV.\xe2\x80\x94Chowder\r\n CHAPTER XVI.\xe2\x80\x94The Ship\r\n CHAPTER XVII.\xe2\x80\x94The Ramadan\r\n CHAPTER XVIII.\xe2\x80\x94His Mark\r\n CHAPTER XIX.\xe2\x80\x94The Prophet\r\n CHAPTER XX.\xe2\x80\x94All Astir\r\n CHAPTER XXI.\xe2\x80\x94Going Aboard\r\n CHAPTER XXII.\xe2\x80\x94Merry Christmas\r\n CHAPTER XXIII.\xe2\x80\x94The Lee Shore\r\n CHAPTER XXIV.\xe2\x80\x94The Advocate\r\n CHAPTER XXV.\xe2\x80\x94Postscript\r\n CHAPTER XXVI.\xe2\x80\x94Knights and Squires\r\n CHAPTER XXVII.\xe2\x80\x94Knights and Squires\r\n CHAPTER XXVIII.\xe2\x80\x94Ahab\r\n CHAPTER XXIX.\xe2\x80\x94Enter Ahab; to him, Stubb\r\n CHAPTER XXX.\xe2\x80\x94The Pipe\r\n CHAPTER XXXI.\xe2\x80\x94Queen Mab\r\n CHAPTER XXXII.\xe2\x80\x94Cetology\r\n CHAPTER XXXIII.\xe2\x80\x94The Specksnyder\r\n CHAPTER XXXIV.\xe2\x80\x94The Cabin Table\r\n CHAPTER XXXV.\xe2\x80\x94The Mast-Head\r\n CHAPTER XXXVI.\xe2\x80\x94The Quarter-Deck. Her Story\r\n CHAPTER LXXII.\xe2\x80\x94The Monkey-rope\r\n CHAPTER LXXIII.\xe2\x80\x94Stubb & Flask kill a Right Whale\r\n CHAPTER LXXIV.\xe2\x80\x94The Sperm Whale\xe2\x80\x99s Head\r\n CHAPTER LXXV.\xe2\x80\x94The Right Whale\xe2\x80\x99s Head\r\n CHAPTER LXXVI.\xe2\x80\x94The Battering Ram\r\n CHAPTER LXXVII.\xe2\x80\x94The Great Heidelburgh Tun\r\n CHAPTER LXXVIII.\xe2\x80\x94Cistern and Buckets\r\n CHAPTER LXXIX.\xe2\x80\x94The Praire\r\n CHAPTER LXXX.\xe2\x80\x94The Nut\r\n CHAPTER LXXXI.\xe2\x80\x94The Pequod meets the Virgin\r\n CHAPTER LXXXII.\xe2\x80\x94The Honor and Glory of Whaling\r\n CHAPTER LXXXIII.\xe2\x80\x94Jonah Historically Regarded\r\n CHAPTER LXXXIV.\xe2\x80\x94Pitchpoling\r\n CHAPTER LXXXV.\xe2\x80\x94The Fountain\r\n CHAPTER LXXXVI.\xe2\x80\x94The Tail\r\n CHAPTER LXXXVII.\xe2\x80\x94The Grand Armada\r\n CHAPTER LXXXVIII.\xe2\x80\x94Schools & Schoolmasters\r\n CHAPTER LXXXIX.\xe2\x80\x94Fast Fish and Loose Fish\r\n CHAPTER XC.\xe2\x80\x94Heads or Tails\r\n CHAPTER XCI.\xe2\x80\x94The Pequod meets the Rose-Bud\r\n CHAPTER XCII.\xe2\x80\x94Ambergris\r\n CHAPTER XCIII.\xe2\x80\x94The Castaway\r\n CHAPTER XCIV.\xe2\x80\x94A Squeeze of the Hand\r\n CHAPTER XCV.\xe2\x80\x94The Cassock\r\n CHAPTER XCVI.\xe2\x80\x94The Try-Works\r\n CHAPTER XCVII.\xe2\x80\x94The Lamp\r\n CHAPTER XCVIII.\xe2\x80\x94Stowing Down and Clearing Up\r\n CHAPTER XCIX.\xe2\x80\x94The Doubloon\r\n CHAPTER C.\xe2\x80\x94The Pequod meets the Samuel Enderby of London\r\n CHAPTER CI.\xe2\x80\x94The Decanter\r\n CHAPTER CII.\xe2\x80\x94A Bower in the Arsacides\r\n CHAPTER CIII.\xe2\x80\x94Measurement of the Whale\xe2\x80\x99s Skeleton\r\n CHAPTER CIV.\xe2\x80\x94The Fossil Whale\r\n CHAPTER CV.\xe2\x80\x94Does the Whale Diminish?\r\n CHAPTER CVI.\xe2\x80\x94Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s Leg\r\n CHAPTER CVII.\xe2\x80\x94The Carpenter\r\n CHAPTER CVIII.\xe2\x80\x94The Deck. Ahab and Pip\r\n CHAPTER CXXXI.\xe2\x80\x94The Hat\r\n CHAPTER CXXXII.\xe2\x80\x94The Pequod meets the Delight\r\n CHAPTER CXXXIII.\xe2\x80\x94The Symphony\r\n CHAPTER CXXXIV.\xe2\x80\x94The Chase. First Day\r\n CHAPTER CXXXV.\xe2\x80\x94The Chase. Second Day\r\n CHAPTER CXXXVI.\xe2\x80\x94The Chase. Third Day\r\n EPILOGUE.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nETYMOLOGY.\r\n\r\n\r\n(Supplied by a late consumptive usher to a grammar school.)\r\n\r\nThe pale Usher\xe2\x80\x94threadbare in coat, heart, body, and brain; I see him\r\nnow. He was ever dusting his old lexicons and grammars, with a queer\r\nhandkerchief, mockingly embellished with all the gay flags of all the\r\nknown nations of the world. He loved to dust his old grammars; it\r\nsomehow mildly reminded him of his mortality.\r\n\r\nETYMOLOGY\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhile you take in hand to school others, and to teach them by what\r\nname a whale-fish is to be called in our tongue, leaving out, through\r\nignorance, the letter H, which almost alone maketh up the signification\r\nof the word, you deliver that which is not true.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Hackluyt._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWHALE. * * * Sw. and Dan. _hval_. This animal is named from roundness\r\nor rolling; for in Dan. _hvalt_ is arched or vaulted.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Webster\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nDictionary._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWHALE. * * * It is more immediately from the Dut. and Ger. _Wallen_;\r\nA.S. _Walw-ian_, to roll, to wallow.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Richardson\xe2\x80\x99s Dictionary._\r\n\r\n\xd7\x97\xd7\x95,                Hebrew_.\r\n\xcf\xb0\xce\xb7\xcf\x84\xce\xbf\xcf\x82,             Greek_.\r\nCETUS,             Latin_.\r\nWH\xc5\x92L,              Anglo-Saxon_.\r\nHVALT,             Danish_.\r\nWAL,               Dutch_.\r\nHWAL,              Swedish_.\r\nHVALUR,            Icelandic_.\r\nWHALE,             English_.\r\nBALEINE,           French_.\r\nBALLENA,           Spanish_.\r\nPEKEE-NUEE-NUEE,   Fegee_.\r\nPEHEE-NUEE-NUEE,   Erromangoan_.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEXTRACTS. (Supplied by a Sub-Sub-Librarian.)\r\n\r\n\r\nIt will be seen that this mere painstaking burrower and grubworm of a\r\npoor devil of a Sub-Sub appears to have gone through the long Vaticans\r\nand street-stalls of the earth, picking up whatever random allusions to\r\nwhales he could anyways find in any book whatsoever, sacred or profane.\r\nTherefore you must not, in every case at least, take the\r\nhiggledy-piggledy whale statements, however authentic, in these\r\nextracts, for veritable gospel cetology. Far from it. As touching the\r\nancient authors generally, as well as the poets here appearing, these\r\nextracts are solely valuable or entertaining, as affording a glancing\r\nbird\xe2\x80\x99s eye view of what has been promiscuously said, thought, fancied,\r\nand sung of Leviathan, by many nations and generations, including our\r\nown.\r\n\r\nSo fare thee well, poor devil of a Sub-Sub, whose commentator I am.\r\nThou belongest to that hopeless, sallow tribe which no wine of this\r\nworld will ever warm; and for whom even Pale Sherry would be too\r\nrosy-strong; but with whom one sometimes loves to sit, and feel\r\npoor-devilish, too; and grow convivial upon tears; and say to them\r\nbluntly, with full eyes and empty glasses, and in not altogether\r\nunpleasant sadness\xe2\x80\x94Give it up, Sub-Subs! For by how much the more pains\r\nye take to please the world, by so much the more shall ye for ever go\r\nthankless! Would that I could clear out Hampton Court and the Tuileries\r\nfor ye! But gulp down your tears and hie aloft to the royal-mast with\r\nyour hearts; for your friends who have gone before are clearing out the\r\nseven-storied heavens, and making refugees of long-pampered Gabriel,\r\nMichael, and Raphael, against your coming. Here ye strike but\r\nsplintered hearts together\xe2\x80\x94there, ye shall strike unsplinterable\r\nglasses!\r\n\r\nEXTRACTS.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd God created great whales.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Genesis_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeviathan maketh a path to shine after him;\r\nOne would think the deep to be hoary.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Job_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow the Lord had prepared a great fish to swallow up Jonah.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Jonah_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere go the ships; there is that Leviathan whom thou hast made to\r\nplay therein.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Psalms_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that day, the Lord with his sore, and great, and strong sword,\r\nshall punish Leviathan the piercing serpent, even Leviathan that\r\ncrooked serpent; and he shall slay the dragon that is in the sea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Isaiah_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what thing soever besides cometh within the chaos of this\r\nmonster\xe2\x80\x99s mouth, be it beast, boat, or stone, down it goes all\r\nincontinently that foul great swallow of his, and perisheth in the\r\nbottomless gulf of his paunch.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Holland\xe2\x80\x99s Plutarch\xe2\x80\x99s Morals_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Indian Sea breedeth the most and the biggest fishes that are:\r\namong which the Whales and Whirlpooles called Bal\xc3\xa6ne, take up as much\r\nin length as four acres or arpens of land.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Holland\xe2\x80\x99s Pliny_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cScarcely had we proceeded two days on the sea, when about sunrise a\r\ngreat many Whales and other monsters of the sea, appeared. Among the\r\nformer, one was of a most monstrous size. * * This came towards us,\r\nopen-mouthed, raising the waves on all sides, and beating the sea\r\nbefore him into a foam.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Tooke\xe2\x80\x99s Lucian_. \xe2\x80\x9c_The True History_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe visited this country also with a view of catching horse-whales,\r\nwhich had bones of very great value for their teeth, of which he\r\nbrought some to the king. * * * The best whales were catched in his own\r\ncountry, of which some were forty-eight, some fifty yards long. He said\r\nthat he was one of six who had killed sixty in two days.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Other or\r\nOcther\xe2\x80\x99s verbal narrative taken down from his mouth by King Alfred,\r\nA.D._ 890.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd whereas all the other things, whether beast or vessel, that enter\r\ninto the dreadful gulf of this monster\xe2\x80\x99s (whale\xe2\x80\x99s) mouth, are\r\nimmediately lost and swallowed up, the sea-gudgeon retires into it in\r\ngreat security, and there sleeps.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94MONTAIGNE. \xe2\x80\x94_Apology for Raimond\r\nSebond_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us fly, let us fly! Old Nick take me if it is not Leviathan\r\ndescribed by the noble prophet Moses in the life of patient Job.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Rabelais_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis whale\xe2\x80\x99s liver was two cartloads.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Stowe\xe2\x80\x99s Annals_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe great Leviathan that maketh the seas to seethe like boiling pan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Lord Bacon\xe2\x80\x99s Version of the Psalms_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTouching that monstrous bulk of the whale or ork we have received\r\nnothing certain. They grow exceeding fat, insomuch that an incredible\r\nquantity of oil will be extracted out of one whale.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Ibid_. \xe2\x80\x9c_History\r\nof Life and Death_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe sovereignest thing on earth is parmacetti for an inward bruise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_King Henry_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery like a whale.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Hamlet_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich to secure, no skill of leach\xe2\x80\x99s art\r\nMote him availle, but to returne againe\r\nTo his wound\xe2\x80\x99s worker, that with lowly dart,\r\nDinting his breast, had bred his restless paine,\r\nLike as the wounded whale to shore flies thro\xe2\x80\x99 the maine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_The Fairie Queen_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImmense as whales, the motion of whose vast bodies can in a peaceful\r\ncalm trouble the ocean till it boil.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Sir William Davenant. Preface\r\nto Gondibert_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat spermacetti is, men might justly doubt, since the learned\r\nHosmannus in his work of thirty years, saith plainly, _Nescio quid\r\nsit_.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Sir T. Browne. Of Sperma Ceti and the Sperma Ceti Whale. Vide\r\nhis V. E._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLike Spencer\xe2\x80\x99s Talus with his modern flail\r\nHe threatens ruin with his ponderous tail.\r\n...\r\nTheir fixed jav\xe2\x80\x99lins in his side he wears,\r\nAnd on his back a grove of pikes appears.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Waller\xe2\x80\x99s Battle of the Summer Islands_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy art is created that great Leviathan, called a Commonwealth or\r\nState\xe2\x80\x94(in Latin, Civitas) which is but an artificial man.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Opening\r\nsentence of Hobbes\xe2\x80\x99s Leviathan_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilly Mansoul swallowed it without chewing, as if it had been a sprat\r\nin the mouth of a whale.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Pilgrim\xe2\x80\x99s Progress_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat sea beast\r\nLeviathan, which God of all his works\r\nCreated hugest that swim the ocean stream.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Paradise Lost_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThere Leviathan,\r\nHugest of living creatures, in the deep\r\nStretched like a promontory sleeps or swims,\r\nAnd seems a moving land; and at his gills\r\nDraws in, and at his breath spouts out a sea.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Ibid_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe mighty whales which swim in a sea of water, and have a sea of oil\r\nswimming in them.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Fuller\xe2\x80\x99s Profane and Holy State_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo close behind some promontory lie\r\n    The huge Leviathan to attend their prey,\r\nAnd give no chance, but swallow in the fry,\r\n    Which through their gaping jaws mistake the way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Dryden\xe2\x80\x99s Annus Mirabilis_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhile the whale is floating at the stern of the ship, they cut off his\r\nhead, and tow it with a boat as near the shore as it will come; but it\r\nwill be aground in twelve or thirteen feet water.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Thomas Edge\xe2\x80\x99s Ten\r\nVoyages to Spitzbergen, in Purchass_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn their way they saw many whales sporting in the ocean, and in\r\nwantonness fuzzing up the water through their pipes and vents, which\r\nnature has placed on their shoulders.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Sir T. Herbert\xe2\x80\x99s Voyages into\r\nAsia and Africa. Harris Coll_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere they saw such huge troops of whales, that they were forced to\r\nproceed with a great deal of caution for fear they should run their\r\nship upon them.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Schouten\xe2\x80\x99s Sixth Circumnavigation_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe set sail from the Elbe, wind N.E. in the ship called The\r\nJonas-in-the-Whale. * * *\r\n\r\nSome say the whale can\xe2\x80\x99t open his mouth, but that is a fable. * * *\r\n\r\nThey frequently climb up the masts to see whether they can see a whale,\r\nfor the first discoverer has a ducat for his pains. * * *\r\n\r\nI was told of a whale taken near Shetland, that had above a barrel of\r\nherrings in his belly. * * *\r\n\r\nOne of our harpooneers told me that he caught once a whale in\r\nSpitzbergen that was white all over.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_A Voyage to Greenland, A.D._\r\n1671. _Harris Coll_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeveral whales have come in upon this coast (Fife) Anno 1652, one\r\neighty feet in length of the whale-bone kind came in, which (as I was\r\ninformed), besides a vast quantity of oil, did afford 500 weight of\r\nbaleen. The jaws of it stand for a gate in the garden of Pitferren.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Sibbald\xe2\x80\x99s Fife and Kinross_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMyself have agreed to try whether I can master and kill this\r\nSperma-ceti whale, for I could never hear of any of that sort that was\r\nkilled by any man, such is his fierceness and swiftness.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Richard\r\nStrafford\xe2\x80\x99s Letter from the Bermudas. Phil. Trans. A.D._ 1668.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhales in the sea\r\nGod\xe2\x80\x99s voice obey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_N. E. Primer_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe saw also abundance of large whales, there being more in those\r\nsouthern seas, as I may say, by a hundred to one; than we have to the\r\nnorthward of us.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Captain Cowley\xe2\x80\x99s Voyage round the Globe, A.D._\r\n1729.\r\n\r\n* * * * * \xe2\x80\x9cand the breath of the whale is frequently attended with such\r\nan insupportable smell, as to bring on a disorder of the brain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Ulloa\xe2\x80\x99s South America_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo fifty chosen sylphs of special note,\r\nWe trust the important charge, the petticoat.\r\nOft have we known that seven-fold fence to fail,\r\nTho\xe2\x80\x99 stuffed with hoops and armed with ribs of whale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Rape of the Lock_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we compare land animals in respect to magnitude, with those that\r\ntake up their abode in the deep, we shall find they will appear\r\ncontemptible in the comparison. The whale is doubtless the largest\r\nanimal in creation.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Goldsmith, Nat. Hist_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you should write a fable for little fishes, you would make them\r\nspeak like great whales.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Goldsmith to Johnson_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the afternoon we saw what was supposed to be a rock, but it was\r\nfound to be a dead whale, which some Asiatics had killed, and were then\r\ntowing ashore. They seemed to endeavor to conceal themselves behind the\r\nwhale, in order to avoid being seen by us.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Cook\xe2\x80\x99s Voyages_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe larger whales, they seldom venture to attack. They stand in so\r\ngreat dread of some of them, that when out at sea they are afraid to\r\nmention even their names, and carry dung, lime-stone, juniper-wood, and\r\nsome other articles of the same nature in their boats, in order to\r\nterrify and prevent their too near approach.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Uno Von Troil\xe2\x80\x99s Letters\r\non Banks\xe2\x80\x99s and Solander\xe2\x80\x99s Voyage to Iceland in_ 1772.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Spermacetti Whale found by the Nantuckois, is an active, fierce\r\nanimal, and requires vast address and boldness in the fishermen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Thomas Jefferson\xe2\x80\x99s Whale Memorial to the French minister in_ 1778.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd pray, sir, what in the world is equal to it?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Edmund Burke\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nreference in Parliament to the Nantucket Whale-Fishery_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpain\xe2\x80\x94a great whale stranded on the shores of Europe.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Edmund\r\nBurke_. (_somewhere_.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA tenth branch of the king\xe2\x80\x99s ordinary revenue, said to be grounded on\r\nthe consideration of his guarding and protecting the seas from pirates\r\nand robbers, is the right to _royal_ fish, which are whale and\r\nsturgeon. And these, when either thrown ashore or caught near the\r\ncoast, are the property of the king.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Blackstone_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSoon to the sport of death the crews repair:\r\nRodmond unerring o\xe2\x80\x99er his head suspends\r\nThe barbed steel, and every turn attends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Falconer\xe2\x80\x99s Shipwreck_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBright shone the roofs, the domes, the spires,\r\n    And rockets blew self driven,\r\nTo hang their momentary fire\r\n    Around the vault of heaven.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo fire with water to compare,\r\n    The ocean serves on high,\r\nUp-spouted by a whale in air,\r\n    To express unwieldy joy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Cowper, on the Queen\xe2\x80\x99s Visit to London_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTen or fifteen gallons of blood are thrown out of the heart at a\r\nstroke, with immense velocity.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_John Hunter\xe2\x80\x99s account of the\r\ndissection of a whale_. (_A small sized one_.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe aorta of a whale is larger in the bore than the main pipe of the\r\nwater-works at London Bridge, and the water roaring in its passage\r\nthrough that pipe is inferior in impetus and velocity to the blood\r\ngushing from the whale\xe2\x80\x99s heart.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Paley\xe2\x80\x99s Theology_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe whale is a mammiferous animal without hind feet.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Baron Cuvier_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn 40 degrees south, we saw Spermacetti Whales, but did not take any\r\ntill the first of May, the sea being then covered with them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Colnett\xe2\x80\x99s Voyage for the Purpose of Extending the Spermacetti Whale\r\nFishery_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the free element beneath me swam,\r\nFloundered and dived, in play, in chace, in battle,\r\nFishes of every color, form, and kind;\r\nWhich language cannot paint, and mariner\r\nHad never seen; from dread Leviathan\r\nTo insect millions peopling every wave:\r\nGather\xe2\x80\x99d in shoals immense, like floating islands,\r\nLed by mysterious instincts through that waste\r\nAnd trackless region, though on every side\r\nAssaulted by voracious enemies,\r\nWhales, sharks, and monsters, arm\xe2\x80\x99d in front or jaw,\r\nWith swords, saws, spiral horns, or hooked fangs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Montgomery\xe2\x80\x99s World before the Flood_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIo! P\xc3\xa6an! Io! sing.\r\nTo the finny people\xe2\x80\x99s king.\r\nNot a mightier whale than this\r\nIn the vast Atlantic is;\r\nNot a fatter fish than he,\r\nFlounders round the Polar Sea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Charles Lamb\xe2\x80\x99s Triumph of the Whale_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the year 1690 some persons were on a high hill observing the whales\r\nspouting and sporting with each other, when one observed:\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x94pointing to the sea\xe2\x80\x94is a green pasture where our children\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngrand-children will go for bread.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Obed Macy\xe2\x80\x99s History of Nantucket_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI built a cottage for Susan and myself and made a gateway in the form\r\nof a Gothic Arch, by setting up a whale\xe2\x80\x99s jaw bones.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Hawthorne\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nTwice Told Tales_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe came to bespeak a monument for her first love, who had been killed\r\nby a whale in the Pacific ocean, no less than forty years ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Ibid_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Sir, \xe2\x80\x99tis a Right Whale,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Tom; \xe2\x80\x9cI saw his spout; he threw\r\nup a pair of as pretty rainbows as a Christian would wish to look at.\r\nHe\xe2\x80\x99s a raal oil-butt, that fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Cooper\xe2\x80\x99s Pilot_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe papers were brought in, and we saw in the Berlin Gazette that\r\nwhales had been introduced on the stage there.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Eckermann\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nConversations with Goethe_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy God! Mr. Chace, what is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d I answered, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have been\r\nstove by a whale.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9c_Narrative of the Shipwreck of the Whale Ship\r\nEssex of Nantucket, which was attacked and finally destroyed by a large\r\nSperm Whale in the Pacific Ocean_.\xe2\x80\x9d _By Owen Chace of Nantucket, first\r\nmate of said vessel. New York_, 1821.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA mariner sat in the shrouds one night,\r\n        The wind was piping free;\r\nNow bright, now dimmed, was the moonlight pale,\r\nAnd the phospher gleamed in the wake of the whale,\r\n        As it floundered in the sea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Elizabeth Oakes Smith_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe quantity of line withdrawn from the different boats engaged in the\r\ncapture of this one whale, amounted altogether to 10,440 yards or\r\nnearly six English miles. * * *\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSometimes the whale shakes its tremendous tail in the air, which,\r\ncracking like a whip, resounds to the distance of three or four miles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Scoresby_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMad with the agonies he endures from these fresh attacks, the\r\ninfuriated Sperm Whale rolls over and over; he rears his enormous head,\r\nand with wide expanded jaws snaps at everything around him; he rushes\r\nat the boats with his head; they are propelled before him with vast\r\nswiftness, and sometimes utterly destroyed. * * *\r\n\r\nIt is a matter of great astonishment that the consideration of the\r\nhabits of so interesting, and, in a commercial point of view, so\r\nimportant an animal (as the Sperm Whale) should have been so entirely\r\nneglected, or should have excited so little curiosity among the\r\nnumerous, and many of them competent observers, that of late years must\r\nhave possessed the most abundant and the most convenient opportunities\r\nof witnessing their habitudes.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Thomas Beale\xe2\x80\x99s History of the Sperm\r\nWhale_, 1839.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Cachalot\xe2\x80\x9d (Sperm Whale) \xe2\x80\x9cis not only better armed than the True\r\nWhale\xe2\x80\x9d (Greenland or Right Whale) \xe2\x80\x9cin possessing a formidable weapon at\r\neither extremity of its body, but also more frequently displays a\r\ndisposition to employ these weapons offensively and in manner at once\r\nso artful, bold, and mischievous, as to lead to its being regarded as\r\nthe most dangerous to attack of all the known species of the whale\r\ntribe.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Frederick Debell Bennett\xe2\x80\x99s Whaling Voyage Round the Globe_,\r\n1840.\r\n\r\nOctober 13. \xe2\x80\x9cThere she blows,\xe2\x80\x9d was sung out from the mast-head.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere away?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded the captain.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree points off the lee bow, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRaise up your wheel. Steady!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSteady, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMast-head ahoy! Do you see that whale now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy ay, sir! A shoal of Sperm Whales! There she blows! There she\r\nbreaches!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSing out! sing out every time!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy Ay, sir! There she blows! there\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x94_thar_ she\r\nblows\xe2\x80\x94bowes\xe2\x80\x94bo-o-os!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow far off?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo miles and a half.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThunder and lightning! so near! Call all hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_J. Ross Browne\xe2\x80\x99s Etchings of a Whaling Cruize_. 1846.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Whale-ship Globe, on board of which vessel occurred the horrid\r\ntransactions we are about to relate, belonged to the island of\r\nNantucket.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9c_Narrative of the Globe Mutiny_,\xe2\x80\x9d _by Lay and Hussey\r\nsurvivors. A.D._ 1828.\r\n\r\nBeing once pursued by a whale which he had wounded, he parried the\r\nassault for some time with a lance; but the furious monster at length\r\nrushed on the boat; himself and comrades only being preserved by\r\nleaping into the water when they saw the onset was inevitable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Missionary Journal of Tyerman and Bennett_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNantucket itself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Webster, \xe2\x80\x9cis a very striking and peculiar\r\nportion of the National interest. There is a population of eight or\r\nnine thousand persons living here in the sea, adding largely every year\r\nto the National wealth by the boldest and most persevering industry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Report of Daniel Webster\xe2\x80\x99s Speech in the U. S. Senate, on the\r\napplication for the Erection of a Breakwater at Nantucket_. 1828.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe whale fell directly over him, and probably killed him in a\r\nmoment.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9c_The Whale and his Captors, or The Whaleman\xe2\x80\x99s Adventures and\r\nthe Whale\xe2\x80\x99s Biography, gathered on the Homeward Cruise of the Commodore\r\nPreble_.\xe2\x80\x9d _By Rev. Henry T. Cheever_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you make the least damn bit of noise,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Samuel, \xe2\x80\x9cI will send\r\nyou to hell.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Life of Samuel Comstock_ (_the mutineer_), _by his\r\nbrother, William Comstock. Another Version of the whale-ship Globe\r\nnarrative_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe voyages of the Dutch and English to the Northern Ocean, in order,\r\nif possible, to discover a passage through it to India, though they\r\nfailed of their main object, laid-open the haunts of the whale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_McCulloch\xe2\x80\x99s Commercial Dictionary_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese things are reciprocal; the ball rebounds, only to bound forward\r\nagain; for now in laying open the haunts of the whale, the whalemen\r\nseem to have indirectly hit upon new clews to that same mystic\r\nNorth-West Passage.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_From_ \xe2\x80\x9c_Something_\xe2\x80\x9d _unpublished_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is impossible to meet a whale-ship on the ocean without being\r\nstruck by her near appearance. The vessel under short sail, with\r\nlook-outs at the mast-heads, eagerly scanning the wide expanse around\r\nthem, has a totally different air from those engaged in regular\r\nvoyage.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Currents and Whaling. U.S. Ex. Ex_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPedestrians in the vicinity of London and elsewhere may recollect\r\nhaving seen large curved bones set upright in the earth, either to form\r\narches over gateways, or entrances to alcoves, and they may perhaps\r\nhave been told that these were the ribs of whales.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Tales of a Whale\r\nVoyager to the Arctic Ocean_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was not till the boats returned from the pursuit of these whales,\r\nthat the whites saw their ship in bloody possession of the savages\r\nenrolled among the crew.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Newspaper Account of the Taking and\r\nRetaking of the Whale-Ship Hobomack_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is generally well known that out of the crews of Whaling vessels\r\n(American) few ever return in the ships on board of which they\r\ndeparted.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Cruise in a Whale Boat_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuddenly a mighty mass emerged from the water, and shot up\r\nperpendicularly into the air. It was the whale.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Miriam Coffin or the\r\nWhale Fisherman_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Whale is harpooned to be sure; but bethink you, how you would\r\nmanage a powerful unbroken colt, with the mere appliance of a rope tied\r\nto the root of his tail.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_A Chapter on Whaling in Ribs and Trucks_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn one occasion I saw two of these monsters (whales) probably male and\r\nfemale, slowly swimming, one after the other, within less than a\r\nstone\xe2\x80\x99s throw of the shore\xe2\x80\x9d (Terra Del Fuego), \xe2\x80\x9cover which the beech\r\ntree extended its branches.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94_Darwin\xe2\x80\x99s Voyage of a Naturalist_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Stern all!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed the mate, as upon turning his head, he saw the\r\ndistended jaws of a large Sperm Whale close to the head of the boat,\r\nthreatening it with instant destruction;\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Stern all, for your lives!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Wharton the Whale Killer_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo be cheery, my lads, let your hearts never fail,\r\nWhile the bold harpooneer is striking the whale!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Nantucket Song_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, the rare old Whale, mid storm and gale\r\n    In his ocean home will be\r\nA giant in might, where might is right,\r\n    And King of the boundless sea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94_Whale Song_.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER I. LOOMINGS\r\n\r\n\r\nCall me Ishmael. Some years ago\xe2\x80\x94never mind how long precisely\xe2\x80\x94having\r\nlittle or no money in my purse, and nothing particular to interest me\r\non shore, I thought I would sail about a little and see the watery part\r\nof the world. It is a way I have of driving off the spleen, and\r\nregulating the circulation. Whenever I find myself growing grim about\r\nthe mouth; whenever it is a damp, drizzly November in my soul; whenever\r\nI find myself involuntarily pausing before coffin warehouses, and\r\nbringing up the rear of every funeral I meet; and especially whenever\r\nmy hypos get such an upper hand of me, that it requires a strong moral\r\nprinciple to prevent me from deliberately stepping into the street, and\r\nmethodically knocking people\xe2\x80\x99s hats off\xe2\x80\x94then, I account it high time to\r\nget to sea as soon as I can. This is my substitute for pistol and ball.\r\nWith a philosophical flourish Cato throws himself upon his sword; I\r\nquietly take to the ship. There is nothing surprising in this. If they\r\nbut knew it, almost all men in their degree, some time or other,\r\ncherish very nearly the same feelings towards the ocean with me.\r\n\r\nThere now is your insular city of the Manhattoes, belted round by\r\nwharves as Indian isles by coral reefs\xe2\x80\x94commerce surrounds it with her\r\nsurf. Right and left, the streets take you waterward. Its extreme\r\ndown-town is the battery, where that noble mole is washed by waves, and\r\ncooled by breezes, which a few hours previous were out of sight of\r\nland. Look at the crowds of water-gazers there.\r\n\r\nCircumambulate the city of a dreamy Sabbath afternoon. Go from Corlears\r\nHook to Coenties Slip, and from thence, by Whitehall northward. What do\r\nyou see?\xe2\x80\x94Posted like silent sentinels all around the town, stand\r\nthousands upon thousands of mortal men fixed in ocean reveries. Some\r\nleaning against the spiles; some seated upon the pier-heads; some\r\nlooking over the bulwarks of ships from China; some high aloft in the\r\nrigging, as if striving to get a still better seaward peep. But these\r\nare all landsmen; of week days pent up in lath and plaster\xe2\x80\x94tied to\r\ncounters, nailed to benches, clinched to desks. How then is this? Are\r\nthe green fields gone? What do they here?\r\n\r\nBut look! here come more crowds, pacing straight for the water, and\r\nseemingly bound for a dive. Strange! Nothing will content them but the\r\nextremest limit of the land; loitering under the shady lee of yonder\r\nwarehouses will not suffice. No. They must get just as nigh the water\r\nas they possibly can without falling in. And there they stand\xe2\x80\x94miles of\r\nthem\xe2\x80\x94leagues. Inlanders all, they come from lanes and alleys, streets\r\nand avenues,\xe2\x80\x94north, east, south, and west. Yet here they all unite.\r\nTell me, does the magnetic virtue of the needles of the compasses of\r\nall those ships attract them thither?\r\n\r\nOnce more. Say, you are in the country; in some high land of lakes.\r\nTake almost any path you please, and ten to one it carries you down in\r\na dale, and leaves you there by a pool in the stream. There is magic in\r\nit. Let the most absent-minded of men be plunged in his deepest\r\nreveries\xe2\x80\x94stand that man on his legs, set his feet a-going, and he will\r\ninfallibly lead you to water, if water there be in all that region.\r\nShould you ever be athirst in the great American desert, try this\r\nexperiment, if your caravan happen to be supplied with a metaphysical\r\nprofessor. Yes, as every one knows, meditation and water are wedded for\r\never.\r\n\r\nBut here is an artist. He desires to paint you the dreamiest, shadiest,\r\nquietest, most enchanting bit of romantic landscape in all the valley\r\nof the Saco. What is the chief element he employs? There stand his\r\ntrees, each with a hollow trunk, as if a hermit and a crucifix were\r\nwithin; and here sleeps his meadow, and there sleep his cattle; and up\r\nfrom yonder cottage goes a sleepy smoke. Deep into distant woodlands\r\nwinds a mazy way, reaching to overlapping spurs of mountains bathed in\r\ntheir hill-side blue. But though the picture lies thus tranced, and\r\nthough this pine-tree shakes down its sighs like leaves upon this\r\nshepherd\xe2\x80\x99s head, yet all were vain, unless the shepherd\xe2\x80\x99s eye were\r\nfixed upon the magic stream before him. Go visit the Prairies in June,\r\nwhen for scores on scores of miles you wade knee-deep among\r\nTiger-lilies\xe2\x80\x94what is the one charm wanting?\xe2\x80\x94Water\xe2\x80\x94there is not a drop\r\nof water there! Were Niagara but a cataract of sand, would you travel\r\nyour thousand miles to see it? Why did the poor poet of Tennessee, upon\r\nsuddenly receiving two handfuls of silver, deliberate whether to buy\r\nhim a coat, which he sadly needed, or invest his money in a pedestrian\r\ntrip to Rockaway Beach? Why is almost every robust healthy boy with a\r\nrobust healthy soul in him, at some time or other crazy to go to sea?\r\nWhy upon your first voyage as a passenger, did you yourself feel such a\r\nmystical vibration, when first told that you and your ship were now out\r\nof sight of land? Why did the old Persians hold the sea holy? Why did\r\nthe Greeks give it a separate deity, and own brother of Jove? Surely\r\nall this is not without meaning. And still deeper the meaning of that\r\nstory of Narcissus, who because he could not grasp the tormenting, mild\r\nimage he saw in the fountain, plunged into it and was drowned. But that\r\nsame image, we ourselves see in all rivers and oceans. It is the image\r\nof the ungraspable phantom of life; and this is the key to it all.\r\n\r\nNow, when I say that I am in the habit of going to sea whenever I begin\r\nto grow hazy about the eyes, and begin to be over conscious of my\r\nlungs, I do not mean to have it inferred that I ever go to sea as a\r\npassenger. For to go as a passenger you must needs have a purse, and a\r\npurse is but a rag unless you have something in it. Besides, passengers\r\nget sea-sick\xe2\x80\x94grow quarrelsome\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t sleep of nights\xe2\x80\x94do not enjoy\r\nthemselves much, as a general thing;\xe2\x80\x94no, I never go as a passenger;\r\nnor, though I am something of a salt, do I ever go to sea as a\r\nCommodore, or a Captain, or a Cook. I abandon the glory and distinction\r\nof such offices to those who like them. For my part, I abominate all\r\nhonorable respectable toils, trials, and tribulations of every kind\r\nwhatsoever. It is quite as much as I can do to take care of myself,\r\nwithout taking care of ships, barques, brigs, schooners, and what not.\r\nAnd as for going as cook,\xe2\x80\x94though I confess there is considerable glory\r\nin that, a cook being a sort of officer on ship-board\xe2\x80\x94yet, somehow, I\r\nnever fancied broiling fowls;\xe2\x80\x94though once broiled, judiciously\r\nbuttered, and judgmatically salted and peppered, there is no one who\r\nwill speak more respectfully, not to say reverentially, of a broiled\r\nfowl than I will. It is out of the idolatrous dotings of the old\r\nEgyptians upon broiled ibis and roasted river horse, that you see the\r\nmummies of those creatures in their huge bake-houses the pyramids.\r\n\r\nNo, when I go to sea, I go as a simple sailor, right before the mast,\r\nplumb down into the forecastle, aloft there to the royal mast-head.\r\nTrue, they rather order me about some, and make me jump from spar to\r\nspar, like a grasshopper in a May meadow. And at first, this sort of\r\nthing is unpleasant enough. It touches one\xe2\x80\x99s sense of honor,\r\nparticularly if you come of an old established family in the land, the\r\nvan Rensselaers, or Randolphs, or Hardicanutes. And more than all, if\r\njust previous to putting your hand into the tar-pot, you have been\r\nlording it as a country schoolmaster, making the tallest boys stand in\r\nawe of you. The transition is a keen one, I assure you, from the\r\nschoolmaster to a sailor, and requires a strong decoction of Seneca and\r\nthe Stoics to enable you to grin and bear it. But even this wears off\r\nin time.\r\n\r\nWhat of it, if some old hunks of a sea-captain orders me to get a broom\r\nand sweep down the decks? What does that indignity amount to, weighed,\r\nI mean, in the scales of the New Testament? Do you think the archangel\r\nGabriel thinks anything the less of me, because I promptly and\r\nrespectfully obey that old hunks in that particular instance? Who aint\r\na slave? Tell me that. Well, then, however the old sea-captains may\r\norder me about\xe2\x80\x94however they may thump and punch me about, I have the\r\nsatisfaction of knowing that it is all right; that everybody else is\r\none way or other served in much the same way\xe2\x80\x94either in a physical or\r\nmetaphysical point of view, that is; and so the universal thump is\r\npassed round, and all hands should rub each other\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder-blades,\r\nand be content.\r\n\r\nAgain, I always go to sea as a sailor, because they make a point of\r\npaying me for my trouble, whereas they never pay passengers a single\r\npenny that I ever heard of. On the contrary, passengers themselves must\r\npay. And there is all the difference in the world between paying and\r\nbeing paid. The act of paying is perhaps the most uncomfortable\r\ninfliction that the two orchard thieves entailed upon us. But _being\r\npaid_,\xe2\x80\x94what will compare with it? The urbane activity with which a man\r\nreceives money is really marvellous, considering that we so earnestly\r\nbelieve money to be the root of all earthly ills, and that on no\r\naccount can a monied man enter heaven. Ah! how cheerfully we consign\r\nourselves to perdition!\r\n\r\nFinally, I always go to sea as a sailor, because of the wholesome\r\nexercise and pure air of the forecastle deck. For as in this world,\r\nhead winds are far more prevalent than winds from astern (that is, if\r\nyou never violate the Pythagorean maxim), so for the most part the\r\nCommodore on the quarter-deck gets his atmosphere at second hand from\r\nthe sailors on the forecastle. He thinks he breathes it first; but not\r\nso. In much the same way do the commonalty lead their leaders in many\r\nother things, at the same time that the leaders little suspect it. But\r\nwherefore it was that after having repeatedly smelt the sea as a\r\nmerchant sailor, I should now take it into my head to go on a whaling\r\nvoyage; this the invisible police officer of the Fates, who has the\r\nconstant surveillance of me, and secretly dogs me, and influences me in\r\nsome unaccountable way\xe2\x80\x94he can better answer than any one else. And,\r\ndoubtless, my going on this whaling voyage, formed part of the grand\r\nprogramme of Providence that was drawn up a long time ago. It came in\r\nas a sort of brief interlude and solo between more extensive\r\nperformances. I take it that this part of the bill must have run\r\nsomething like this:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Grand Contested Election for the Presidency of the United States._\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWHALING VOYAGE BY ONE ISHMAEL.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBLOODY BATTLE IN AFFGHANISTAN.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThough I cannot tell why it was exactly that those stage managers, the\r\nFates, put me down for this shabby part of a whaling voyage, when\r\nothers were set down for magnificent parts in high tragedies, and short\r\nand easy parts in genteel comedies, and jolly parts in farces\xe2\x80\x94though I\r\ncannot tell why this was exactly; yet, now that I recall all the\r\ncircumstances, I think I can see a little into the springs and motives\r\nwhich being cunningly presented to me under various disguises, induced\r\nme to set about performing the part I did, besides cajoling me into the\r\ndelusion that it was a choice resulting from my own unbiased freewill\r\nand discriminating judgment.\r\n\r\nChief among these motives was the overwhelming idea of the great whale\r\nhimself. Such a portentous and mysterious monster roused all my\r\ncuriosity. Then the wild and distant seas where he rolled his island\r\nbulk; the undeliverable, nameless perils of the whale; these, with all\r\nthe attending marvels of a thousand Patagonian sights and sounds,\r\nhelped to sway me to my wish. With other men, perhaps, such things\r\nwould not have been inducements; but as for me, I am tormented with an\r\neverlasting itch for things remote. I love to sail forbidden seas, and\r\nland on barbarous coasts. Not ignoring what is good, I am quick to\r\nperceive a horror, and could still be social with it\xe2\x80\x94would they let\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94since it is but well to be on friendly terms with all the inmates of\r\nthe place one lodges in.\r\n\r\nBy reason of these things, then, the whaling voyage was welcome; the\r\ngreat flood-gates of the wonder-world swung open, and in the wild\r\nconceits that swayed me to my purpose, two and two there floated into\r\nmy inmost soul, endless processions of the whale, and, mid most of them\r\nall, one grand hooded phantom, like a snow hill in the air.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER II. THE CARPET-BAG\r\n\r\n\r\nI stuffed a shirt or two into my old carpet-bag, tucked it under my\r\narm, and started for Cape Horn and the Pacific. Quitting the good city\r\nof old Manhatto, I duly arrived in New Bedford. It was on a Saturday\r\nnight in December. Much was I disappointed upon learning that the\r\nlittle packet for Nantucket had already sailed, and that no way of\r\nreaching that place would offer, till the following Monday.\r\n\r\nAs most young candidates for the pains and penalties of whaling stop at\r\nthis same New Bedford, thence to embark on their voyage, it may as well\r\nbe related that I, for one, had no idea of so doing. For my mind was\r\nmade up to sail in no other than a Nantucket craft, because there was a\r\nfine, boisterous something about everything connected with that famous\r\nold island, which amazingly pleased me. Besides though New Bedford has\r\nof late been gradually monopolizing the business of whaling, and though\r\nin this matter poor old Nantucket is now much behind her, yet Nantucket\r\nwas her great original\xe2\x80\x94the Tyre of this Carthage;\xe2\x80\x94the place where the\r\nfirst dead American whale was stranded. Where else but from Nantucket\r\ndid those aboriginal whalemen, the Red-Men, first sally out in canoes\r\nto give chase to the Leviathan? And where but from Nantucket, too, did\r\nthat first adventurous little sloop put forth, partly laden with\r\nimported cobble-stones\xe2\x80\x94so goes the story\xe2\x80\x94to throw at the whales, in\r\norder to discover when they were nigh enough to risk a harpoon from the\r\nbowsprit?\r\n\r\nNow having a night, a day, and still another night following before me\r\nin New Bedford, ere I could embark for my destined port, it became a\r\nmatter of concernment where I was to eat and sleep meanwhile. It was a\r\nvery dubious-looking, nay, a very dark and dismal night, bitingly cold\r\nand cheerless. I knew no one in the place. With anxious grapnels I had\r\nsounded my pocket, and only brought up a few pieces of silver,\xe2\x80\x94So,\r\nwherever you go, Ishmael, said I to myself, as I stood in the middle of\r\na dreary street shouldering my bag, and comparing the gloom towards the\r\nnorth with the darkness towards the south\xe2\x80\x94wherever in your wisdom you\r\nmay conclude to lodge for the night, my dear Ishmael, be sure to\r\ninquire the price, and don\xe2\x80\x99t be too particular.\r\n\r\nWith halting steps I paced the streets, and passed the sign of \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nCrossed Harpoons\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94but it looked too expensive and jolly there. Further\r\non, from the bright red windows of the \xe2\x80\x9cSword-Fish Inn,\xe2\x80\x9d there came\r\nsuch fervent rays, that it seemed to have melted the packed snow and\r\nice from before the house, for everywhere else the congealed frost lay\r\nten inches thick in a hard, asphaltic pavement,\xe2\x80\x94rather weary for me,\r\nwhen I struck my foot against the flinty projections, because from\r\nhard, remorseless service the soles of my boots were in a most\r\nmiserable plight. Too expensive and jolly, again thought I, pausing one\r\nmoment to watch the broad glare in the street, and hear the sounds of\r\nthe tinkling glasses within. But go on, Ishmael, said I at last; don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyou hear? get away from before the door; your patched boots are\r\nstopping the way. So on I went. I now by instinct followed the streets\r\nthat took me waterward, for there, doubtless, were the cheapest, if not\r\nthe cheeriest inns.\r\n\r\nSuch dreary streets! Blocks of blackness, not houses, on either hand,\r\nand here and there a candle, like a candle moving about in a tomb. At\r\nthis hour of the night, of the last day of the week, that quarter of\r\nthe town proved all but deserted. But presently I came to a smoky light\r\nproceeding from a low, wide building, the door of which stood\r\ninvitingly open. It had a careless look, as if it were meant for the\r\nuses of the public; so, entering, the first thing I did was to stumble\r\nover an ash-box in the porch. Ha! thought I, ha, as the flying\r\nparticles almost choked me, are these ashes from that destroyed city,\r\nGomorrah? But \xe2\x80\x9cThe Crossed Harpoons,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cThe Sword-Fish?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94this, then,\r\nmust needs be the sign of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Trap.\xe2\x80\x9d However, I picked myself up and\r\nhearing a loud voice within, pushed on and opened a second, interior\r\ndoor.\r\n\r\nIt seemed the great Black Parliament sitting in Tophet. A hundred black\r\nfaces turned round in their rows to peer; and beyond, a black Angel of\r\nDoom was beating a book in a pulpit. It was a negro church; and the\r\npreacher\xe2\x80\x99s text was about the blackness of darkness, and the weeping\r\nand wailing and teeth-gnashing there. Ha, Ishmael, muttered I, backing\r\nout, Wretched entertainment at the sign of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Trap!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMoving on, I at last came to a dim sort of light not far from the\r\ndocks, and heard a forlorn creaking in the air; and looking up, saw a\r\nswinging sign over the door with a white painting upon it, faintly\r\nrepresenting a tall straight jet of misty spray, and these words\r\nunderneath\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThe Spouter-Inn:\xe2\x80\x94Peter Coffin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCoffin?\xe2\x80\x94Spouter?\xe2\x80\x94Rather ominous in that particular connexion, thought\r\nI. But it is a common name in Nantucket, they say, and I suppose this\r\nPeter here is an emigrant from there. As the light looked so dim, and\r\nthe place, for the time, looked quiet enough, and the dilapidated\r\nlittle wooden house itself looked as if it might have been carted here\r\nfrom the ruins of some burnt district, and as the swinging sign had a\r\npoverty-stricken sort of creak to it, I thought that here was the very\r\nspot for cheap lodgings, and the best of pea coffee.\r\n\r\nIt was a queer sort of place\xe2\x80\x94a gable-ended old house, one side palsied\r\nas it were, and leaning over sadly. It stood on a sharp bleak corner,\r\nwhere that tempestuous wind Euroclydon kept up a worse howling than\r\never it did about poor Paul\xe2\x80\x99s tossed craft. Euroclydon, nevertheless,\r\nis a mighty pleasant zephyr to any one in-doors, with his feet on the\r\nhob quietly toasting for bed. \xe2\x80\x9cIn judging of that tempestuous wind\r\ncalled Euroclydon,\xe2\x80\x9d says an old writer\xe2\x80\x94of whose works I possess the\r\nonly copy extant\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cit maketh a marvellous difference, whether thou\r\nlookest out at it from a glass window where the frost is all on the\r\noutside, or whether thou observest it from that sashless window, where\r\nthe frost is on both sides, and of which the wight Death is the only\r\nglazier.\xe2\x80\x9d True enough, thought I, as this passage occurred to my\r\nmind\xe2\x80\x94old black-letter, thou reasonest well. Yes, these eyes are\r\nwindows, and this body of mine is the house. What a pity they didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nstop up the chinks and the crannies though, and thrust in a little lint\r\nhere and there. But it\xe2\x80\x99s too late to make any improvements now. The\r\nuniverse is finished; the copestone is on, and the chips were carted\r\noff a million years ago. Poor Lazarus there, chattering his teeth\r\nagainst the curbstone for his pillow, and shaking off his tatters with\r\nhis shiverings, he might plug up both ears with rags, and put a\r\ncorn-cob into his mouth, and yet that would not keep out the\r\ntempestuous Euroclydon. Euroclydon! says old Dives, in his red silken\r\nwrapper\xe2\x80\x94(he had a redder one afterwards) pooh, pooh! What a fine frosty\r\nnight; how Orion glitters; what northern lights! Let them talk of their\r\noriental summer climes of everlasting conservatories; give me the\r\nprivilege of making my own summer with my own coals.\r\n\r\nBut what thinks Lazarus? Can he warm his blue hands by holding them up\r\nto the grand northern lights? Would not Lazarus rather be in Sumatra\r\nthan here? Would he not far rather lay him down lengthwise along the\r\nline of the equator; yea, ye gods! go down to the fiery pit itself, in\r\norder to keep out this frost?\r\n\r\nNow, that Lazarus should lie stranded there on the curbstone before the\r\ndoor of Dives, this is more wonderful than that an iceberg should be\r\nmoored to one of the Moluccas. Yet Dives himself, he too lives like a\r\nCzar in an ice palace made of frozen sighs, and being a president of a\r\ntemperance society, he only drinks the tepid tears of orphans.\r\n\r\nBut no more of this blubbering now, we are going a-whaling, and there\r\nis plenty of that yet to come. Let us scrape the ice from our frosted\r\nfeet, and see what sort of a place this \xe2\x80\x9cSpouter\xe2\x80\x9d may be.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER III. THE SPOUTER-INN\r\n\r\n\r\nEntering that gable-ended Spouter-Inn, you found yourself in a wide,\r\nlow, straggling entry with old-fashioned wainscots, reminding one of\r\nthe bulwarks of some condemned old craft. On one side hung a very large\r\noil-painting so thoroughly besmoked, and every way defaced, that in the\r\nunequal cross-lights by which you viewed it, it was only by diligent\r\nstudy and a series of systematic visits to it, and careful inquiry of\r\nthe neighbors, that you could any way arrive at an understanding of its\r\npurpose. Such unaccountable masses of shades and shadows, that at first\r\nyou almost thought some ambitious young artist, in the time of the New\r\nEngland hags, had endeavored to delineate chaos bewitched. But by dint\r\nof much and earnest contemplation, and oft repeated ponderings, and\r\nespecially by throwing open the little window towards the back of the\r\nentry, you at last come to the conclusion that such an idea, however\r\nwild, might not be altogether unwarranted.\r\n\r\nBut what most puzzled and confounded you was a long, limber,\r\nportentous, black mass of something hovering in the centre of the\r\npicture over three blue, dim, perpendicular lines floating in a\r\nnameless yeast. A boggy, soggy, squitchy picture truly, enough to drive\r\na nervous man distracted. Yet was there a sort of indefinite,\r\nhalf-attained, unimaginable sublimity about it that fairly froze you to\r\nit, till you involuntarily took an oath with yourself to find out what\r\nthat marvellous painting meant. Ever and anon a bright, but, alas,\r\ndeceptive idea would dart you through.\xe2\x80\x94It\xe2\x80\x99s the Black Sea in a midnight\r\ngale.\xe2\x80\x94It\xe2\x80\x99s the unnatural combat of the four primal elements.\xe2\x80\x94It\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nblasted heath.\xe2\x80\x94It\xe2\x80\x99s a Hyperborean winter scene.\xe2\x80\x94It\xe2\x80\x99s the breaking-up of\r\nthe ice-bound stream of Time. But at last all these fancies yielded to\r\nthat one portentous something in the picture\xe2\x80\x99s midst. _That_ once found\r\nout, and all the rest were plain. But stop; does it not bear a faint\r\nresemblance to a gigantic fish? even the great leviathan himself?\r\n\r\nIn fact, the artist\xe2\x80\x99s design seemed this: a final theory of my own,\r\npartly based upon the aggregated opinions of many aged persons with\r\nwhom I conversed upon the subject. The picture represents a Cape-Horner\r\nin a great hurricane; the half-foundered ship weltering there with its\r\nthree dismantled masts alone visible; and an exasperated whale,\r\npurposing to spring clean over the craft, is in the enormous act of\r\nimpaling himself upon the three mast-heads.\r\n\r\nThe opposite wall of this entry was hung all over with a heathenish\r\narray of monstrous clubs and spears. Some were thickly set with\r\nglittering teeth resembling ivory saws; others were tufted with knots\r\nof human hair; and one was sickle-shaped, with a vast handle sweeping\r\nround like the segment made in the new-mown grass by a long-armed\r\nmower. You shuddered as you gazed, and wondered what monstrous cannibal\r\nand savage could ever have gone a death-harvesting with such a hacking,\r\nhorrifying implement. Mixed with these were rusty old whaling lances\r\nand harpoons all broken and deformed. Some were storied weapons. With\r\nthis once long lance, now wildly elbowed, fifty years ago did Nathan\r\nSwain kill fifteen whales between a sunrise and a sunset. And that\r\nharpoon\xe2\x80\x94so like a corkscrew now\xe2\x80\x94was flung in Javan seas, and run away\r\nwith by a whale, years afterward slain off the Cape of Blanco. The\r\noriginal iron entered nigh the tail, and, like a restless needle\r\nsojourning in the body of a man, travelled full forty feet, and at last\r\nwas found imbedded in the hump.\r\n\r\nCrossing this dusky entry, and on through yon low-arched way\xe2\x80\x94cut\r\nthrough what in old times must have been a great central chimney with\r\nfire-places all round\xe2\x80\x94you enter the public room. A still duskier place\r\nis this, with such low ponderous beams above, and such old wrinkled\r\nplanks beneath, that you would almost fancy you trod some old craft\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncockpits, especially of such a howling night, when this corner-anchored\r\nold ark rocked so furiously. On one side stood a long, low, shelf-like\r\ntable covered with cracked glass cases, filled with dusty rarities\r\ngathered from this wide world\xe2\x80\x99s remotest nooks. Projecting from the\r\nfurther angle of the room stands a dark-looking den\xe2\x80\x94the bar\xe2\x80\x94a rude\r\nattempt at a right whale\xe2\x80\x99s head. Be that how it may, there stands the\r\nvast arched bone of the whale\xe2\x80\x99s jaw, so wide, a coach might almost\r\ndrive beneath it. Within are shabby shelves, ranged round with old\r\ndecanters, bottles, flasks; and in those jaws of swift destruction,\r\nlike another cursed Jonah (by which name indeed they called him),\r\nbustles a little withered old man, who, for their money, dearly sells\r\nthe sailors deliriums and death.\r\n\r\nAbominable are the tumblers into which he pours his poison. Though true\r\ncylinders without\xe2\x80\x94within, the villanous green goggling glasses\r\ndeceitfully tapered downwards to a cheating bottom. Parallel meridians\r\nrudely pecked into the glass, surround these footpads\xe2\x80\x99 goblets. Fill to\r\n_this_ mark, and your charge is but a penny; to _this_ a penny more;\r\nand so on to the full glass\xe2\x80\x94the Cape Horn measure, which you may gulp\r\ndown for a shilling.\r\n\r\nUpon entering the place I found a number of young seamen gathered about\r\na table, examining by a dim light divers specimens of _skrimshander_. I\r\nsought the landlord, and telling him I desired to be accommodated with\r\na room, received for answer that his house was full\xe2\x80\x94not a bed\r\nunoccupied. \xe2\x80\x9cBut avast,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, tapping his forehead, \xe2\x80\x9cyou haint no\r\nobjections to sharing a harpooneer\xe2\x80\x99s blanket, have ye? I s\xe2\x80\x99pose you are\r\ngoin\xe2\x80\x99 a whalin\xe2\x80\x99, so you\xe2\x80\x99d better get used to that sort of thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI told him that I never liked to sleep two in a bed; that if I should\r\never do so, it would depend upon who the harpooneer might be, and that\r\nif he (the landlord) really had no other place for me, and the\r\nharpooneer was not decidedly objectionable, why rather than wander\r\nfurther about a strange town on so bitter a night, I would put up with\r\nthe half of any decent man\xe2\x80\x99s blanket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought so. All right; take a seat. Supper?\xe2\x80\x94you want supper? Supper\r\n\xe2\x80\x99ll be ready directly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI sat down on an old wooden settle, carved all over like a bench on the\r\nBattery. At one end a ruminating tar was still further adorning it with\r\nhis jack-knife, stooping over and diligently working away at the space\r\nbetween his legs. He was trying his hand at a ship under full sail, but\r\nhe didn\xe2\x80\x99t make much headway, I thought.\r\n\r\nAt last some four or five of us were summoned to our meal in an\r\nadjoining room. It was cold as Iceland\xe2\x80\x94no fire at all\xe2\x80\x94the landlord said\r\nhe couldn\xe2\x80\x99t afford it. Nothing but two dismal tallow candles, each in a\r\nwinding sheet. We were fain to button up our monkey jackets, and hold\r\nto our lips cups of scalding tea with our half frozen fingers. But the\r\nfare was of the most substantial kind\xe2\x80\x94not only meat and potatoes, but\r\ndumplings; good heavens! dumplings for supper! One young fellow in a\r\ngreen box coat, addressed himself to these dumplings in a most direful\r\nmanner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said the landlord, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ll have the nightmare to a dead\r\nsartainty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLandlord,\xe2\x80\x9d I whispered, \xe2\x80\x9cthat aint the harpooneer, is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, looking a sort of diabolically funny, \xe2\x80\x9cthe\r\nharpooneer is a dark complexioned chap. He never eats dumplings, he\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t\xe2\x80\x94he eats nothing but steaks, and likes \xe2\x80\x99em rare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil he does,\xe2\x80\x9d says I. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere is that harpooneer? Is he here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99ll be here afore long,\xe2\x80\x9d was the answer.\r\n\r\nI could not help it, but I began to feel suspicious of this \xe2\x80\x9cdark\r\ncomplexioned\xe2\x80\x9d harpooneer. At any rate, I made up my mind that if it so\r\nturned out that we should sleep together, he must undress and get into\r\nbed before I did.\r\n\r\nSupper over, the company went back to the bar-room, when, knowing not\r\nwhat else to do with myself, I resolved to spend the rest of the\r\nevening as a looker on.\r\n\r\nPresently a rioting noise was heard without. Starting up, the landlord\r\ncried, \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the Grampus\xe2\x80\x99s crew. I seed her reported in the offing\r\nthis morning; a three years\xe2\x80\x99 voyage, and a full ship. Hurrah, boys; now\r\nwe\xe2\x80\x99ll have the latest news from the Feegees.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA tramping of sea boots was heard in the entry; the door was flung\r\nopen, and in rolled a wild set of mariners enough. Enveloped in their\r\nshaggy watch coats, and with their heads muffled in woollen comforters,\r\nall bedarned and ragged, and their beards stiff with icicles, they\r\nseemed an eruption of bears from Labrador. They had just landed from\r\ntheir boat, and this was the first house they entered. No wonder, then,\r\nthat they made a straight wake for the whale\xe2\x80\x99s mouth\xe2\x80\x94the bar\xe2\x80\x94when the\r\nwrinkled little old Jonah, there officiating, soon poured them out\r\nbrimmers all round. One complained of a bad cold in his head, upon\r\nwhich Jonah mixed him a pitch-like potion of gin and molasses, which he\r\nswore was a sovereign cure for all colds and catarrhs whatsoever, never\r\nmind of how long standing, or whether caught off the coast of Labrador,\r\nor on the weather side of an ice-island.\r\n\r\nThe liquor soon mounted into their heads, as it generally does even\r\nwith the arrantest topers newly landed from sea, and they began\r\ncapering about most obstreperously.\r\n\r\nI observed, however, that one of them held somewhat aloof, and though\r\nhe seemed desirous not to spoil the hilarity of his shipmates by his\r\nown sober face, yet upon the whole he refrained from making as much\r\nnoise as the rest. This man interested me at once; and since the\r\nsea-gods had ordained that he should soon become my shipmate (though\r\nbut a sleeping-partner one, so far as this narrative is concerned), I\r\nwill here venture upon a little description of him. He stood full six\r\nfeet in height, with noble shoulders, and a chest like a coffer-dam. I\r\nhave seldom seen such brawn in a man. His face was deeply brown and\r\nburnt, making his white teeth dazzling by the contrast; while in the\r\ndeep shadows of his eyes floated some reminiscences that did not seem\r\nto give him much joy. His voice at once announced that he was a\r\nSoutherner, and from his fine stature, I thought he must be one of\r\nthose tall mountaineers from the Alleganian Ridge in Virginia. When the\r\nrevelry of his companions had mounted to its height, this man slipped\r\naway unobserved, and I saw no more of him till he became my comrade on\r\nthe sea. In a few minutes, however, he was missed by his shipmates, and\r\nbeing, it seems, for some reason a huge favorite with them, they raised\r\na cry of \xe2\x80\x9cBulkington! Bulkington! where\xe2\x80\x99s Bulkington?\xe2\x80\x9d and darted out\r\nof the house in pursuit of him.\r\n\r\nIt was now about nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and the room seeming almost\r\nsupernaturally quiet after these orgies, I began to congratulate myself\r\nupon a little plan that had occurred to me just previous to the\r\nentrance of the seamen.\r\n\r\nNo man prefers to sleep two in a bed. In fact, you would a good deal\r\nrather not sleep with your own brother. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how it is, but\r\npeople like to be private when they are sleeping. And when it comes to\r\nsleeping with an unknown stranger, in a strange inn, in a strange town,\r\nand that stranger a harpooneer, then your objections indefinitely\r\nmultiply. Nor was there any earthly reason why I as a sailor should\r\nsleep two in a bed, more than anybody else; for sailors no more sleep\r\ntwo in a bed at sea, than bachelor Kings do ashore. To be sure they all\r\nsleep together in one apartment, but you have your own hammock, and\r\ncover yourself with your own blanket, and sleep in your own skin.\r\n\r\nThe more I pondered over this harpooneer, the more I abominated the\r\nthought of sleeping with him. It was fair to presume that being a\r\nharpooneer, his linen or woollen, as the case might be, would not be of\r\nthe tidiest, certainly none of the finest. I began to twitch all over.\r\nBesides, it was getting late, and my decent harpooneer ought to be home\r\nand going bedwards. Suppose now, he should tumble in upon me at\r\nmidnight\xe2\x80\x94how could I tell from what vile hole he had been coming?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLandlord! I\xe2\x80\x99ve changed my mind about that harpooneer.\xe2\x80\x94I shan\xe2\x80\x99t sleep\r\nwith him. I\xe2\x80\x99ll try the bench here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust as you please; I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry I cant spare ye a tablecloth for a\r\nmattress, and it\xe2\x80\x99s a plaguy rough board here\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94feeling of the knots and\r\nnotches. \xe2\x80\x9cBut wait a bit, Skrimshander; I\xe2\x80\x99ve got a carpenter\xe2\x80\x99s plane\r\nthere in the bar\xe2\x80\x94wait, I say, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll make ye snug enough.\xe2\x80\x9d So saying\r\nhe procured the plane; and with his old silk handkerchief first dusting\r\nthe bench, vigorously set to planing away at my bed, the while grinning\r\nlike an ape. The shavings flew right and left; till at last the\r\nplane-iron came bump against an indestructible knot. The landlord was\r\nnear spraining his wrist, and I told him for heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake to quit\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nbed was soft enough to suit me, and I did not know how all the planing\r\nin the world could make eider down of a pine plank. So gathering up the\r\nshavings with another grin, and throwing them into the great stove in\r\nthe middle of the room, he went about his business, and left me in a\r\nbrown study.\r\n\r\nI now took the measure of the bench, and found that it was a foot too\r\nshort; but that could be mended with a chair. But it was a foot too\r\nnarrow, and the other bench in the room was about four inches higher\r\nthan the planed one\xe2\x80\x94so there was no yoking them. I then placed the\r\nfirst bench lengthwise along the only clear space against the wall,\r\nleaving a little interval between, for my back to settle down in. But I\r\nsoon found that there came such a draught of cold air over me from\r\nunder the sill of the window, that this plan would never do at all,\r\nespecially as another current from the rickety door met the one from\r\nthe window, and both together formed a series of small whirlwinds in\r\nthe immediate vicinity of the spot where I had thought to spend the\r\nnight.\r\n\r\nThe devil fetch that harpooneer, thought I, but stop, couldn\xe2\x80\x99t I steal\r\na march on him\xe2\x80\x94bolt his door inside, and jump into his bed, not to be\r\nwakened by the most violent knockings? It seemed no bad idea; but upon\r\nsecond thoughts I dismissed it. For who could tell but what the next\r\nmorning, so soon as I popped out of the room, the harpooneer might be\r\nstanding in the entry, all ready to knock me down!\r\n\r\nStill, looking around me again, and seeing no possible chance of\r\nspending a sufferable night unless in some other person\xe2\x80\x99s bed, I began\r\nto think that after all I might be cherishing unwarrantable prejudices\r\nagainst this unknown harpooneer. Thinks I, I\xe2\x80\x99ll wait awhile; he must be\r\ndropping in before long. I\xe2\x80\x99ll have a good look at him then, and perhaps\r\nwe may become jolly good bedfellows after all\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99s no telling.\r\n\r\nBut though the other boarders kept coming in by ones, twos, and threes,\r\nand going to bed, yet no sign of my harpooneer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLandlord!\xe2\x80\x9d said I, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat sort of a chap is he\xe2\x80\x94does he always keep such\r\nlate hours?\xe2\x80\x9d It was now hard upon twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\r\n\r\nThe landlord chuckled again with his lean chuckle, and seemed to be\r\nmightily tickled at something beyond my comprehension. \xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nanswered, \xe2\x80\x9cgenerally he\xe2\x80\x99s an early bird\xe2\x80\x94airley to bed and airley to\r\nrise\xe2\x80\x94yes, he\xe2\x80\x99s the bird what catches the worm.\xe2\x80\x94But to-night he went out\r\na peddling, you see, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t see what on airth keeps him so late,\r\nunless, may be, he can\xe2\x80\x99t sell his head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t sell his head?\xe2\x80\x94What sort of a bamboozingly story is this you are\r\ntelling me?\xe2\x80\x9d getting into a towering rage. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you pretend to say,\r\nlandlord, that this harpooneer is actually engaged this blessed\r\nSaturday night, or rather Sunday morning, in peddling his head around\r\nthis town?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s precisely it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the landlord, \xe2\x80\x9cand I told him he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nsell it here, the market\xe2\x80\x99s overstocked.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith what?\xe2\x80\x9d shouted I.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith heads to be sure; ain\xe2\x80\x99t there too many heads in the world?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you what it is, landlord,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, quite calmly, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99d better\r\nstop spinning that yarn to me\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99m not green.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay be not,\xe2\x80\x9d taking out a stick and whittling a toothpick, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I\r\nrayther guess you\xe2\x80\x99ll be done _brown_ if that ere harpooneer hears you a\r\nslanderin\xe2\x80\x99 his head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll break it for him,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, now flying into a passion again at\r\nthis unaccountable farrago of the landlord\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s broke a\xe2\x80\x99ready,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBroke,\xe2\x80\x9d said I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9c_broke_, do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSartain, and that\xe2\x80\x99s the very reason he can\xe2\x80\x99t sell it, I guess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLandlord,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, going up to him as cool as Mt. Hecla in a snow\r\nstorm,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9clandlord, stop whittling. You and I must understand one\r\nanother, and that too without delay. I come to your house and want a\r\nbed; you tell me you can only give me half a one; that the other half\r\nbelongs to a certain harpooneer. And about this harpooneer, whom I have\r\nnot yet seen, you persist in telling me the most mystifying and\r\nexasperating stories, tending to beget in me an uncomfortable feeling\r\ntowards the man whom you design for my bedfellow\xe2\x80\x94a sort of connexion,\r\nlandlord, which is an intimate and confidential one in the highest\r\ndegree. I now demand of you to speak out and tell me who and what this\r\nharpooneer is, and whether I shall be in all respects safe to spend the\r\nnight with him. And in the first place, you will be so good as to unsay\r\nthat story about selling his head, which if true I take to be good\r\nevidence that this harpooneer is stark mad, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve no idea of\r\nsleeping with a madman; and you, sir, _you_ I mean, landlord, _you_,\r\nsir, by trying to induce me to do so knowingly, would thereby render\r\nyourself liable to a criminal prosecution.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWall,\xe2\x80\x9d said the landlord, fetching a long breath, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s a purty long\r\nsarmon for a chap that rips a little now and then. But be easy, be\r\neasy, this here harpooneer I have been tellin\xe2\x80\x99 you of has just arrived\r\nfrom the south seas, where he bought up a lot of \xe2\x80\x99balmed New Zealand\r\nheads (great curios, you know), and he\xe2\x80\x99s sold all on \xe2\x80\x99em but one, and\r\nthat one he\xe2\x80\x99s trying to sell to-night, cause to-morrow\xe2\x80\x99s Sunday, and it\r\nwould not do to be sellin\xe2\x80\x99 human heads about the streets when folks is\r\ngoin\xe2\x80\x99 to churches. He wanted to, last Sunday, but I stopped him just as\r\nhe was goin\xe2\x80\x99 out of the door with four heads strung on a string, for\r\nall the airth like a string of inions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis account cleared up the otherwise unaccountable mystery, and showed\r\nthat the landlord, after all, had had no idea of fooling me\xe2\x80\x94but at the\r\nsame time what could I think of a harpooneer who stayed out a Saturday\r\nnight clean into the holy Sabbath, engaged in such a cannibal business\r\nas selling the heads of dead idolators?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDepend upon it, landlord, that harpooneer is a dangerous man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe pays reg\xe2\x80\x99lar,\xe2\x80\x9d was the rejoinder. \xe2\x80\x9cBut come, it\xe2\x80\x99s getting dreadful\r\nlate, you had better be turning flukes\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s a nice bed: Sal and me\r\nslept in that ere bed the night we were spliced. There\xe2\x80\x99s plenty room\r\nfor two to kick about in that bed; it\xe2\x80\x99s an almighty big bed that. Why,\r\nafore we give it up, Sal used to put our Sam and little Johnny in the\r\nfoot of it. But I got a dreaming and sprawling about one night, and\r\nsomehow, Sam got pitched on the floor, and came near breaking his arm.\r\nAfter that, Sal said it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do. Come along here, I\xe2\x80\x99ll give ye a\r\nglim in a jiffy;\xe2\x80\x9d and so saying he lighted a candle and held it towards\r\nme, offering to lead the way. But I stood irresolute; when looking at a\r\nclock in the corner, he exclaimed \xe2\x80\x9cI vum it\xe2\x80\x99s Sunday\xe2\x80\x94you won\xe2\x80\x99t see that\r\nharpooneer to-night; he\xe2\x80\x99s come to anchor somewhere\xe2\x80\x94come along then;\r\n_do_ come; _won\xe2\x80\x99t_ ye come?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI considered the matter a moment, and then up stairs we went, and I was\r\nushered into a small room, cold as a clam, and furnished, sure enough,\r\nwith a prodigious bed, almost big enough indeed for any four\r\nharpooneers to sleep abreast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere,\xe2\x80\x9d said the landlord, placing the candle on a crazy old sea chest\r\nthat did double duty as a wash-stand and centre table; \xe2\x80\x9cthere, make\r\nyourself comfortable now, and good night to ye.\xe2\x80\x9d I turned round from\r\neyeing the bed, but he had disappeared.\r\n\r\nFolding back the counterpane, I stooped over the bed. Though none of\r\nthe most elegant, it yet stood the scrutiny tolerably well. I then\r\nglanced round the room; and besides the bedstead and centre table,\r\ncould see no other furniture belonging to the place, but a rude shelf,\r\nthe four walls, and a papered fireboard representing a man striking a\r\nwhale. Of things not properly belonging to the room, there was a\r\nhammock lashed up, and thrown upon the floor in one corner; also a\r\nlarge seaman\xe2\x80\x99s bag, containing the harpooneer\xe2\x80\x99s wardrobe, no doubt in\r\nlieu of a land trunk. Likewise, there was a parcel of outlandish bone\r\nfish hooks on the shelf over the fire-place, and a tall harpoon\r\nstanding at the head of the bed.\r\n\r\nBut what is this on the chest? I took it up, and held it close to the\r\nlight, and felt it, and smelt it, and tried every way possible to\r\narrive at some satisfactory conclusion concerning it. I can compare it\r\nto nothing but a large door mat, ornamented at the edges with little\r\ntinkling tags something like the stained porcupine quills round an\r\nIndian moccasin. There was a hole or slit in the middle of this mat, as\r\nyou see the same in South American ponchos.
