These eyes of mine look into the very eye that is even now\r\nbeholding him; aye, and into the eye that is even now equally beholding\r\nthe objects on the unknown, thither side of thee, thou sun!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen gazing at his quadrant, and handling, one after the other, its\r\nnumerous cabalistical contrivances, he pondered again, and muttered:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFoolish toy! babies\xe2\x80\x99 plaything of haughty Admirals, and Commodores,\r\nand Captains; the world brags of thee, of thy cunning and might; but\r\nwhat after all canst thou do, but tell the poor, pitiful point, where\r\nthou thyself happenest to be on this wide planet, and the hand that\r\nholds thee: no! not one jot more! Thou canst not tell where one drop of\r\nwater or one grain of sand will be to-morrow noon; and yet with thy\r\nimpotence thou insultest the sun! Science! Curse thee, thou vain toy;\r\nand cursed be all the things that cast man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes aloft to that heaven,\r\nwhose live vividness but scorches him, as these old eyes are even now\r\nscorched with thy light, O sun! Level by nature to this earth\xe2\x80\x99s horizon\r\nare the glances of man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes; not shot from the crown of his head, as\r\nif God had meant him to gaze on his firmament. Curse thee, thou\r\nquadrant!\xe2\x80\x9d dashing it to the deck, \xe2\x80\x9cno longer will I guide my earthly\r\nway by thee; the level ship\xe2\x80\x99s compass, and the level dead-reckoning, by\r\nlog and by line; _these_ shall conduct me, and show me my place on the\r\nsea. Aye,\xe2\x80\x9d lighting from the boat to the deck, \xe2\x80\x9cthus I trample on thee,\r\nthou paltry thing that feebly pointest on high; thus I split and\r\ndestroy thee!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs the frantic old man thus spoke and thus trampled with his live and\r\ndead feet, a sneering triumph that seemed meant for Ahab, and a\r\nfatalistic despair that seemed meant for himself\xe2\x80\x94these passed over the\r\nmute, motionless Parsee\xe2\x80\x99s face. Unobserved he rose and glided away;\r\nwhile, awestruck by the aspect of their commander, the seamen clustered\r\ntogether on the forecastle, till Ahab, troubledly pacing the deck,\r\nshouted out\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cTo the braces! Up helm!\xe2\x80\x94square in!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn an instant the yards swung round; and as the ship half-wheeled upon\r\nher heel, her three firm-seated graceful masts erectly poised upon her\r\nlong, ribbed hull, seemed as the three Horatii pirouetting on one\r\nsufficient steed.\r\n\r\nStanding between the knight-heads, Starbuck watched the Pequod\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntumultuous way, and Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s also, as he went lurching along the deck.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have sat before the dense coal fire and watched it all aglow, full\r\nof its tormented flaming life; and I have seen it wane at last, down,\r\ndown, to dumbest dust. Old man of oceans! of all this fiery life of\r\nthine, what will at length remain but one little heap of ashes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Stubb, \xe2\x80\x9cbut sea-coal ashes\xe2\x80\x94mind ye that, Mr.\r\nStarbuck\xe2\x80\x94sea-coal, not your common charcoal. Well, well; I heard Ahab\r\nmutter, \xe2\x80\x98Here some one thrusts these cards into these old hands of\r\nmine; swears that I must play them, and no others.\xe2\x80\x99 And damn me, Ahab,\r\nbut thou actest right; live in the game, and die it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER CXIX. THE CANDLES\r\n\r\n\r\nWarmest climes but nurse the cruellest fangs: the tiger of Bengal\r\ncrouches in spiced groves of ceaseless verdure. Skies the most\r\neffulgent but basket the deadliest thunders: gorgeous Cuba knows\r\ntornadoes that never swept tame northern lands. So, too, it is, that in\r\nthese resplendent Japanese seas the mariner encounters the direst of\r\nall storms, the Typhoon. It will sometimes burst from out that\r\ncloudless sky, like an exploding bomb upon a dazed and sleepy town.\r\n\r\nTowards evening of that day, the Pequod was torn of her canvas, and\r\nbare-poled was left to fight a Typhoon which had struck her directly\r\nahead. When darkness came on, sky and sea roared and split with the\r\nthunder, and blazed with the lightning, that showed the disabled masts\r\nfluttering here and there with the rags which the first fury of the\r\ntempest had left for its after sport.\r\n\r\nHolding by a shroud, Starbuck was standing on the quarter-deck; at\r\nevery flash of the lightning glancing aloft, to see what additional\r\ndisaster might have befallen the intricate hamper there; while Stubb\r\nand Flask were directing the men in the higher hoisting and firmer\r\nlashing of the boats. But all their pains seemed naught. Though lifted\r\nto the very top of the cranes, the windward quarter boat (Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s) did\r\nnot escape. A great rolling sea, dashing high up against the reeling\r\nship\xe2\x80\x99s high tetering side, stove in the boat\xe2\x80\x99s bottom at the stern, and\r\nleft it again, all dripping through like a sieve.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBad work, bad work!\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Starbuck, said Stubb, regarding the wreck,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut the sea will have its way. Stubb, for one, can\xe2\x80\x99t fight it. You\r\nsee, Mr. Starbuck, a wave has such a great long start before it leaps,\r\nall round the world it runs, and then comes the spring! But as for me,\r\nall the start I have to meet it, is just across the deck here. But\r\nnever mind; it\xe2\x80\x99s all in fun: so the old song says;\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94(_sings_.)\r\n\r\nOh! jolly is the gale,\r\nAnd a joker is the whale,\r\nA\xe2\x80\x99 flourishin\xe2\x80\x99 his tail,\xe2\x80\x94\r\nSuch a funny, sporty, gamy, jesty, joky, hoky-poky lad, is the Ocean,\r\noh!\r\n\r\nThe scud all a flyin\xe2\x80\x99,\r\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s his flip only foamin\xe2\x80\x99;\r\nWhen he stirs in the spicin\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x94\r\nSuch a funny, sporty, gamy, jesty, joky, hoky-poky lad, is the Ocean,\r\noh!\r\n\r\nThunder splits the ships,\r\nBut he only smacks his lips,\r\nA tastin\xe2\x80\x99 of this flip,\xe2\x80\x94\r\nSuch a funny, sporty, gamy, jesty, joky, hoky-poky lad, is the Ocean,\r\noh!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAvast Stubb,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Starbuck, \xe2\x80\x9clet the Typhoon sing, and strike his\r\nharp here in our rigging; but if thou art a brave man thou wilt hold\r\nthy peace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I am not a brave man; never said I was a brave man; I am a coward;\r\nand I sing to keep up my spirits. And I tell you what it is, Mr.\r\nStarbuck, there\xe2\x80\x99s no way to stop my singing in this world but to cut my\r\nthroat. And when that\xe2\x80\x99s done, ten to one I sing ye the doxology for a\r\nwind-up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadman! look through my eyes if thou hast none of thine own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! how can you see better of a dark night than anybody else, never\r\nmind how foolish?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Starbuck, seizing Stubb by the shoulder, and pointing his\r\nhand towards the weather bow, \xe2\x80\x9cmarkest thou not that the gale comes\r\nfrom the eastward, the very course Ahab is to run for Moby Dick? the\r\nvery course he swung to this day noon? now mark his boat there; where\r\nis that stove? In the stern-sheets, man; where he is wont to stand\xe2\x80\x94his\r\nstand-point is stove, man! Now jump overboard, and sing away, if thou\r\nmust!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t half understand ye: what\xe2\x80\x99s in the wind?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, round the Cape of Good Hope is the shortest way to\r\nNantucket,\xe2\x80\x9d soliloquized Starbuck suddenly, heedless of Stubb\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nquestion. \xe2\x80\x9cThe gale that now hammers at us to stave us, we can turn it\r\ninto a fair wind that will drive us towards home. Yonder, to windward,\r\nall is blackness of doom; but to leeward, homeward\xe2\x80\x94I see it lightens up\r\nthere; but not with the lightning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt that moment in one of the intervals of profound darkness, following\r\nthe flashes, a voice was heard at his side; and almost at the same\r\ninstant a volley of thunder peals rolled overhead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho\xe2\x80\x99s there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOld Thunder!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ahab, groping his way along the bulwarks to his\r\npivot-hole; but suddenly finding his path made plain to him by elbowed\r\nlances of fire.\r\n\r\nNow, as the lightning rod to a spire on shore is intended to carry off\r\nthe perilous fluid into the soil; so the kindred rod which at sea some\r\nships carry to each mast, is intended to conduct it into the water. But\r\nas this conductor must descend to considerable depth, that its end may\r\navoid all contact with the hull; and as moreover, if kept constantly\r\ntowing there, it would be liable to many mishaps, besides interfering\r\nnot a little with some of the rigging, and more or less impeding the\r\nvessel\xe2\x80\x99s way in the water; because of all this, the lower parts of a\r\nship\xe2\x80\x99s lightning-rods are not always overboard; but are generally made\r\nin long slender links, so as to be the more readily hauled up into the\r\nchains outside, or thrown down into the sea, as occasion may require.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe rods! the rods!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Starbuck to the crew, suddenly admonished\r\nto vigilance by the vivid lightning that had just been darting\r\nflambeaux, to light Ahab to his post. \xe2\x80\x9cAre they overboard? drop them\r\nover, fore and aft. Quick!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAvast!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ahab; \xe2\x80\x9clet\xe2\x80\x99s have fair play here, though we be the\r\nweaker side. Yet I\xe2\x80\x99ll contribute to raise rods on the Himmalehs and\r\nAndes, that all the world may be secured; but out on privileges! Let\r\nthem be, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook aloft!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Starbuck. \xe2\x80\x9cThe corpusants! the corpusants!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll the yard-arms were tipped with a pallid fire; and touched at each\r\ntri-pointed lightning-rod-end with three tapering white flames, each of\r\nthe three tall masts was silently burning in that sulphurous air, like\r\nthree gigantic wax tapers before an altar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBlast the boat! let it go!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Stubb at this instant, as a swashing\r\nsea heaved up under his own little craft, so that its gunwale violently\r\njammed his hand, as he was passing a lashing. \xe2\x80\x9cBlast it!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94but slipping\r\nbackward on the deck, his uplifted eyes caught the flames; and\r\nimmediately shifting his tone, he cried\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThe corpusants have mercy on\r\nus all!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo sailors, oaths are household words; they will swear in the trance of\r\nthe calm, and in the teeth of the tempest; they will imprecate curses\r\nfrom the topsail-yard-arms, when most they teter over to a seething\r\nsea; but in all my voyagings, seldom have I heard a common oath when\r\nGod\xe2\x80\x99s burning finger has been laid on the ship; when His \xe2\x80\x9cMene, Mene,\r\nTekel Upharsin\xe2\x80\x9d has been woven into the shrouds and the cordage.\r\n\r\nWhile this pallidness was burning aloft, few words were heard from the\r\nenchanted crew; who in one thick cluster stood on the forecastle, all\r\ntheir eyes gleaming in that pale phosphorescence, like a far away\r\nconstellation of stars. Relieved against the ghostly light, the\r\ngigantic jet negro, Daggoo, loomed up to thrice his real stature, and\r\nseemed the black cloud from which the thunder had come. The parted\r\nmouth of Tashtego revealed his shark-white teeth, which strangely\r\ngleamed as if they too had been tipped by corpusants; while lit up by\r\nthe preternatural light, Queequeg\xe2\x80\x99s tattooing burned like Satanic blue\r\nflames on his body.\r\n\r\nThe tableau all waned at last with the pallidness aloft; and once more\r\nthe Pequod and every soul on her decks were wrapped in a pall. A moment\r\nor two passed, when Starbuck, going forward, pushed against some one.\r\nIt was Stubb. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat thinkest thou now, man; I heard thy cry; it was not\r\nthe same in the song.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t; I said the corpusants have mercy on us all; and I\r\nhope they will, still. But do they only have mercy on long faces?\xe2\x80\x94have\r\nthey no bowels for a laugh? And look ye, Mr. Starbuck\xe2\x80\x94but it\xe2\x80\x99s too dark\r\nto look. Hear me, then: I take that mast-head flame we saw for a sign\r\nof good luck; for those masts are rooted in a hold that is going to be\r\nchock a\xe2\x80\x99 block with sperm-oil, d\xe2\x80\x99ye see; and so, all that sperm will\r\nwork up into the masts, like sap in a tree. Yes, our three masts will\r\nyet be as three spermaceti candles\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s the good promise we saw.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt that moment Starbuck caught sight of Stubb\xe2\x80\x99s face slowly beginning\r\nto glimmer into sight. Glancing upwards, he cried: \xe2\x80\x9cSee! see!\xe2\x80\x9d and once\r\nmore the high tapering flames were beheld with what seemed redoubled\r\nsupernaturalness in their pallor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe corpusants have mercy on us all,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Stubb, again.\r\n\r\nAt the base of the mainmast, full beneath the doubloon and the flame,\r\nthe parsee was kneeling in Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s front, but with his head bowed away\r\nfrom him; while near by, from the arched and overhanging rigging, where\r\nthey had just been engaged securing a spar, a number of the seamen,\r\narrested by the glare, now cohered together, and hung pendulous, like a\r\nknot of numbed wasps from a drooping, orchard twig. In various\r\nenchanted attitudes, like the standing, or stepping, or running\r\nskeletons in Herculaneum, others remained rooted to the deck; but all\r\ntheir eyes upcast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye, aye, men!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ahab. \xe2\x80\x9cLook up at it; mark it well; the white\r\nflame but lights the way to the White Whale! Hand me those main-mast\r\nlinks there; I would fain feel this pulse, and let mine beat against\r\nit; blood against fire! So.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen turning\xe2\x80\x94the last link held fast in his left hand, he put his foot\r\nupon the Parsee; and with fixed upward eye, and high-flung right arm,\r\nhe stood erect before the lofty tri-pointed trinity of flames.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! thou clear spirit of clear fire, whom on these seas I as Persian\r\nonce did worship, till in the sacramental act so burned by thee, that\r\nto this hour I bear the scar; I now know thee, thou clear spirit, and I\r\nnow know that thy right worship is defiance. To neither love nor\r\nreverence wilt thou be kind; and e\xe2\x80\x99en for hate thou canst but kill; and\r\nall are killed. No fearless fool now fronts thee. I own thy speechless,\r\nplaceless power; but to the last gasp of my earthquake life will\r\ndispute its unconditional, unintegral mastery in me. In the midst of\r\nthe personified impersonal, a personality stands here. Though but a\r\npoint at best; whencesoe\xe2\x80\x99er I came; wheresoe\xe2\x80\x99er I go; yet while I\r\nearthly live, the queenly personality lives in me, and feels her royal\r\nrights. But war is pain, and hate is woe. Come in thy lowest form of\r\nlove, and I will kneel and kiss thee; but at thy highest, come as mere\r\nsupernal power; and though thou launchest navies of full-freighted\r\nworlds, there\xe2\x80\x99s that in here that still remains indifferent. Oh, thou\r\nclear spirit, of thy fire thou madest me, and like a true child of\r\nfire, I breathe it back to thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[_Sudden, repeated flashes of lightning; the nine flames leap\r\nlengthwise to thrice their previous height; Ahab, with the rest, closes\r\nhis eyes, his right hand pressed hard upon them._]\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI own thy speechless, placeless power; said I not so? Nor was it wrung\r\nfrom me; nor do I now drop these links. Thou canst blind; but I can\r\nthen grope. Thou canst consume; but I can then be ashes. Take the\r\nhomage of these poor eyes, and shutter-hands. I would not take it. The\r\nlightning flashes through my skull; mine eye-balls ache and ache; my\r\nwhole beaten brain seems as beheaded, and rolling on some stunning\r\nground. Oh, oh! Yet blindfold, yet will I talk to thee. Light though\r\nthou be, thou leapest out of darkness; but I am darkness leaping out of\r\nlight, leaping out of thee! The javelins cease; open eyes; see, or not?\r\nThere burn the flames! Oh, thou magnanimous! now do I glory in my\r\ngenealogy. But thou art but my fiery father; my sweet mother, I know\r\nnot. Oh, cruel! what hast thou done with her? There lies my puzzle; but\r\nthine is greater. Thou knowest not how came ye, hence callest thyself\r\nunbegotten; certainly knowest not thy beginning, hence callest thyself\r\nunbegun. I know that of me, which thou knowest not of thyself, oh, thou\r\nomnipotent. There is some unsuffusing thing beyond thee, thou clear\r\nspirit, to whom all thy eternity is but time, all thy creativeness\r\nmechanical. Through thee, thy flaming self, my scorched eyes do dimly\r\nsee it. Oh, thou foundling fire, thou hermit immemorial, thou too hast\r\nthy incommunicable riddle, thy unparticipated grief. Here again with\r\nhaughty agony, I read my sire. Leap! leap up, and lick the sky! I leap\r\nwith thee; I burn with thee; would fain be welded with thee; defyingly\r\nI worship thee!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe boat! the boat!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Starbuck, \xe2\x80\x9clook at thy boat, old man!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAhab\xe2\x80\x99s harpoon, the one forged at Perth\xe2\x80\x99s fire, remained firmly lashed\r\nin its conspicuous crotch, so that it projected beyond his whale-boat\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbow; but the sea that had stove its bottom had caused the loose leather\r\nsheath to drop off; and from the keen steel barb there now came a\r\nlevelled flame of pale, forked fire. As the silent harpoon burned there\r\nlike a serpent\xe2\x80\x99s tongue, Starbuck grasped Ahab by the arm\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cGod, God is\r\nagainst thee, old man; forbear! \xe2\x80\x99tis an ill voyage! ill begun, ill\r\ncontinued; let me square the yards, while we may, old man, and make a\r\nfair wind of it homewards, to go on a better voyage than this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOverhearing Starbuck, the panic-stricken crew instantly ran to the\r\nbraces\xe2\x80\x94though not a sail was left aloft. For the moment all the aghast\r\nmate\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts seemed theirs; they raised a half mutinous cry. But\r\ndashing the rattling lightning links to the deck, and snatching the\r\nburning harpoon, Ahab waved it like a torch among them; swearing to\r\ntransfix with it the first sailor that but cast loose a rope\xe2\x80\x99s end.\r\nPetrified by his aspect, and still more shrinking from the fiery dart\r\nthat he held, the men fell back in dismay, and Ahab again spoke:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll your oaths to hunt the White Whale are as binding as mine; and\r\nheart, soul, and body, lungs and life, old Ahab is bound. And that ye\r\nmay know to what tune this heart beats; look ye here; thus I blow out\r\nthe last fear!\xe2\x80\x9d And with one blast of his breath he extinguished the\r\nflame.\r\n\r\nAs in the hurricane that sweeps the plain, men fly the neighborhood of\r\nsome lone, gigantic elm, whose very height and strength but render it\r\nso much the more unsafe, because so much the more a mark for\r\nthunderbolts; so at those last words of Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s many of the mariners did\r\nrun from him in a terror of dismay.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER CXX. THE DECK TOWARDS THE END OF THE FIRST NIGHT WATCH\r\n\r\n\r\n_Ahab standing by the helm. Starbuck approaching him._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must send down the main-top-sail yard, sir. The band is working\r\nloose, and the lee lift is half-stranded. Shall I strike it, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStrike nothing; lash it. If I had sky-sail poles, I\xe2\x80\x99d sway them up\r\nnow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir?\xe2\x80\x94in God\xe2\x80\x99s name!\xe2\x80\x94sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe anchors are working, sir. Shall I get them inboard?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStrike nothing, and stir nothing, but lash everything. The wind rises,\r\nbut it has not got up to my table-lands yet. Quick, and see to it.\xe2\x80\x94By\r\nmasts and keels! he takes me for the hunch-backed skipper of some\r\ncoasting smack. Send down my main-top-sail yard! Ho, gluepots! Loftiest\r\ntrucks were made for wildest winds, and this brain-truck of mine now\r\nsails amid the cloud-scud. Shall I strike that? Oh, none but cowards\r\nsend down their brain-trucks in tempest time. What a hooroosh aloft\r\nthere! I would e\xe2\x80\x99en take it for sublime, did I not know that the colic\r\nis a noisy malady. Oh, take medicine, take medicine!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER CXXI. MIDNIGHT\xe2\x80\x94THE FORECASTLE BULWARKS\r\n\r\n\r\n_Stubb and Flask mounted on them, and passing additional lashings over\r\nthe anchors there hanging._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Stubb; you may pound that knot there as much as you please, but\r\nyou will never pound into me what you were just now saying. And how\r\nlong ago is it since you said the very contrary? Didn\xe2\x80\x99t you once say\r\nthat whatever ship Ahab sails in, that ship should pay something extra\r\non its insurance policy, just as though it were loaded with powder\r\nbarrels aft and boxes of lucifers forward? Stop, now; didn\xe2\x80\x99t you say\r\nso?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, suppose I did? What then? I\xe2\x80\x99ve part changed my flesh since that\r\ntime, why not my mind? Besides, supposing we are loaded with powder\r\nbarrels aft and lucifers forward; how the devil could the lucifers get\r\nafire in this drenching spray here? Why, my little man, you have pretty\r\nred hair, but you couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get afire now. Shake yourself; you\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nAquarius, or the water-bearer, Flask; might fill pitchers at your coat\r\ncollar. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you see, then, that for these extra risks the Marine\r\nInsurance companies have extra guarantees? Here are hydrants, Flask.\r\nBut hark, again, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll answer ye the other thing. First take your\r\nleg off from the crown of the anchor here, though, so I can pass the\r\nrope; now listen. What\xe2\x80\x99s the mighty difference between holding a mast\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlightning-rod in the storm, and standing close by a mast that hasn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ngot any lightning-rod at all in a storm? Don\xe2\x80\x99t you see, you\r\ntimber-head, that no harm can come to the holder of the rod, unless the\r\nmast is first struck? What are you talking about, then? Not one ship in\r\na hundred carries rods, and Ahab,\xe2\x80\x94aye, man, and all of us,\xe2\x80\x94were in no\r\nmore danger then, in my poor opinion, than all the crews in ten\r\nthousand ships now sailing the seas. Why, you King-Post, you, I suppose\r\nyou would have every man in the world go about with a small\r\nlightning-rod running up the corner of his hat, like a militia\r\nofficer\xe2\x80\x99s skewered feather, and trailing behind like his sash. Why\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t ye be sensible, Flask? it\xe2\x80\x99s easy to be sensible; why don\xe2\x80\x99t ye,\r\nthen? any man with half an eye can be sensible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know that, Stubb. You sometimes find it rather hard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, when a fellow\xe2\x80\x99s soaked through, it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to be sensible, that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\na fact. And I am about drenched with this spray. Never mind; catch the\r\nturn there, and pass it. Seems to me we are lashing down these anchors\r\nnow as if they were never going to be used again. Tying these two\r\nanchors here, Flask, seems like tying a man\xe2\x80\x99s hands behind him. And\r\nwhat big generous hands they are, to be sure. These are your iron\r\nfists, hey? What a hold they have, too! I wonder, Flask, whether the\r\nworld is anchored anywhere; if she is, she swings with an uncommon long\r\ncable, though. There, hammer that knot down, and we\xe2\x80\x99ve done. So; next\r\nto touching land, lighting on deck is the most satisfactory. I say,\r\njust wring out my jacket skirts, will ye? Thank ye. They laugh at\r\nlong-togs so, Flask; but seems to me, a long tailed coat ought always\r\nto be worn in all storms afloat. The tails tapering down that way,\r\nserve to carry off the water, d\xe2\x80\x99ye see. Same with cocked hats; the\r\ncocks form gable-end eave-troughs, Flask. No more monkey-jackets and\r\ntarpaulins for me; I must mount a swallow-tail, and drive down a\r\nbeaver; so. Halloa! whew! there goes my tarpaulin overboard; Lord,\r\nLord, that the winds that come from heaven should be so unmannerly!\r\nThis is a nasty night, lad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER CXXII. MIDNIGHT ALOFT\xe2\x80\x94THUNDER AND LIGHTNING\r\n\r\n\r\n_The Main-top-sail yard.\xe2\x80\x94Tashtego passing new lashings around it._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUm, um, um. Stop that thunder! Plenty too much thunder up here. What\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthe use of thunder? Um, um, um. We don\xe2\x80\x99t want thunder; we want rum;\r\ngive us a glass of rum. Um, um, um!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER CXXIII. THE MUSKET\r\n\r\n\r\nDuring the most violent shocks of the Typhoon, the man at the Pequod\xe2\x80\x99s\r\njaw-bone tiller had several times been reelingly hurled to the deck by\r\nits spasmodic motions, even though preventer tackles had been attached\r\nto it\xe2\x80\x94for they were slack\xe2\x80\x94because some play to the tiller was\r\nindispensable.\r\n\r\nIn a severe gale like this, while the ship is but a tossed shuttle-cock\r\nto the blast, it is by no means uncommon to see the needles in the\r\ncompasses, at intervals, go round and round. It was thus with the\r\nPequod\xe2\x80\x99s; at almost every shock the helmsman had not failed to notice\r\nthe whirling velocity with which they revolved upon the cards; it is a\r\nsight that hardly any one can behold without some sort of unwonted\r\nemotion.\r\n\r\nSome hours after midnight, the Typhoon abated so much, that through the\r\nstrenuous exertions of Starbuck and Stubb\xe2\x80\x94one engaged forward and the\r\nother aft\xe2\x80\x94the shivered remnants of the jib and fore and main-top-sails\r\nwere cut adrift from the spars, and went eddying away to leeward, like\r\nthe feathers of an albatross, which sometimes are cast to the winds\r\nwhen that storm-tossed bird is on the wing.\r\n\r\nThe three corresponding new sails were now bent and reefed, and a\r\nstorm-trysail was set further aft; so that the ship soon went through\r\nthe water with some precision again; and the course\xe2\x80\x94for the present,\r\nEast-south-east\xe2\x80\x94which he was to steer, if practicable, was once more\r\ngiven to the helmsman. For during the violence of the gale, he had only\r\nsteered according to its vicissitudes. But as he was now bringing the\r\nship as near her course as possible, watching the compass meanwhile,\r\nlo! a good sign! the wind seemed coming round astern; aye! the foul\r\nbreeze became fair!\r\n\r\nInstantly the yards were squared, to the lively song of \xe2\x80\x9c_Ho! the fair\r\nwind! oh-he-yo, cheerly, men!_\xe2\x80\x9d the crew singing for joy, that so\r\npromising an event should so soon have falsified the evil portents\r\npreceding it.\r\n\r\nIn compliance with the standing order of his commander\xe2\x80\x94to report\r\nimmediately, and at any one of the twenty-four hours, any decided\r\nchange in the affairs of the deck,\xe2\x80\x94Starbuck had no sooner trimmed the\r\nyards to the breeze\xe2\x80\x94however reluctantly and gloomily,\xe2\x80\x94than he\r\nmechanically went below to apprise Captain Ahab of the circumstance.\r\n\r\nEre knocking at his state-room, he involuntarily paused before it a\r\nmoment. The cabin lamp\xe2\x80\x94taking long swings this way and that\xe2\x80\x94was burning\r\nfitfully, and casting fitful shadows upon the old man\xe2\x80\x99s bolted door,\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nthin one, with fixed blinds inserted, in place of upper panels. The\r\nisolated subterraneousness of the cabin made a certain humming silence\r\nto reign there, though it was hooped round by all the roar of the\r\nelements. The loaded muskets in the rack were shiningly revealed, as\r\nthey stood upright against the forward bulkhead. Starbuck was an\r\nhonest, upright man; but out of Starbuck\xe2\x80\x99s heart, at that instant when\r\nhe saw the muskets, there strangely evolved an evil thought; but so\r\nblent with its neutral or good accompaniments that for the instant he\r\nhardly knew it for itself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe would have shot me once,\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured, \xe2\x80\x9cyes, there\xe2\x80\x99s the very\r\nmusket that he pointed at me;\xe2\x80\x94that one with the studded stock; let me\r\ntouch it\xe2\x80\x94lift it. Strange, that I, who have handled so many deadly\r\nlances, strange, that I should shake so now. Loaded? I must see. Aye,\r\naye; and powder in the pan;\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s not good. Best spill it?\xe2\x80\x94wait. I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\ncure myself of this. I\xe2\x80\x99ll hold the musket boldly while I think.\xe2\x80\x94I come\r\nto report a fair wind to him. But how fair? Fair for death and\r\ndoom,\xe2\x80\x94_that\xe2\x80\x99s_ fair for Moby Dick. It\xe2\x80\x99s a fair wind that\xe2\x80\x99s only fair\r\nfor that accursed fish.\xe2\x80\x94The very tube he pointed at me!\xe2\x80\x94the very one;\r\n_this_ one\xe2\x80\x94I hold it here; he would have killed me with the very thing\r\nI handle now.\xe2\x80\x94Aye and he would fain kill all his crew. Does he not say\r\nhe will not strike his spars to any gale? Has he not dashed his\r\nheavenly quadrant? and in these same perilous seas, gropes he not his\r\nway by mere dead reckoning of the error-abounding log? and in this very\r\nTyphoon, did he not swear that he would have no lightning-rods? But\r\nshall this crazed old man be tamely suffered to drag a whole ship\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncompany down to doom with him?\xe2\x80\x94Yes, it would make him the wilful\r\nmurderer of thirty men and more, if this ship come to any deadly harm;\r\nand come to deadly harm, my soul swears this ship will, if Ahab have\r\nhis way. If, then, he were this instant\xe2\x80\x94put aside, that crime would not\r\nbe his. Ha! is he muttering in his sleep? Yes, just there,\xe2\x80\x94in there,\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99s sleeping. Sleeping? aye, but still alive, and soon awake again. I\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t withstand thee, then, old man. Not reasoning; not remonstrance;\r\nnot entreaty wilt thou hearken to; all this thou scornest. Flat\r\nobedience to thy own flat commands, this is all thou breathest. Aye,\r\nand say\xe2\x80\x99st the men have vow\xe2\x80\x99d thy vow; say\xe2\x80\x99st all of us are Ahabs.\r\nGreat God forbid!\xe2\x80\x94But is there no other way? no lawful way?\xe2\x80\x94Make him a\r\nprisoner to be taken home? What! hope to wrest this old man\xe2\x80\x99s living\r\npower from his own living hands? Only a fool would try it. Say he were\r\npinioned even; knotted all over with ropes and hawsers; chained down to\r\nring-bolts on this cabin floor; he would be more hideous than a caged\r\ntiger, then. I could not endure the sight; could not possibly fly his\r\nhowlings; all comfort, sleep itself, inestimable reason would leave me\r\non the long intolerable voyage. What, then, remains? The land is\r\nhundreds of leagues away, and locked Japan the nearest. I stand alone\r\nhere upon an open sea, with two oceans and a whole continent between me\r\nand law.\xe2\x80\x94Aye, aye, \xe2\x80\x99tis so.\xe2\x80\x94Is heaven a murderer when its lightning\r\nstrikes a would-be murderer in his bed, tindering sheets and skin\r\ntogether?\xe2\x80\x94And would I be a murderer, then, if\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and slowly, stealthily,\r\nand half sideways looking, he placed the loaded musket\xe2\x80\x99s end against\r\nthe door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn this level, Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s hammock swings within; his head this way. A\r\ntouch, and Starbuck may survive to hug his wife and child again.\xe2\x80\x94Oh\r\nMary! Mary!\xe2\x80\x94boy! boy! boy!\xe2\x80\x94But if I wake thee not to death, old man,\r\nwho can tell to what unsounded deeps Starbuck\xe2\x80\x99s body this day week may\r\nsink, with all the crew! Great God, where art thou? Shall I? shall\r\nI?\xe2\x80\x94The wind has gone down and shifted, sir; the fore and main topsails\r\nare reefed and set; she heads her course.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStern all! Oh Moby Dick, I clutch thy heart at last!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSuch were the sounds that now came hurtling from out the old man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntormented sleep, as if Starbuck\xe2\x80\x99s voice had caused the long dumb dream\r\nto speak.\r\n\r\nThe yet levelled musket shook like a drunkard\xe2\x80\x99s arm against the panel;\r\nStarbuck seemed wrestling with an angel; but turning from the door, he\r\nplaced the death-tube in its rack, and left the place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s too sound asleep, Mr Stubb; go thou down, and wake him, and tell\r\nhim. I must see to the deck here. Thou know\xe2\x80\x99st what to say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER CXXIV. THE NEEDLE\r\n\r\n\r\nNext morning the not-yet-subsided sea rolled in long slow billows of\r\nmighty bulk, and striving in the Pequod\xe2\x80\x99s gurgling track, pushed her on\r\nlike giants\xe2\x80\x99 palms outspread. The strong, unstaggering breeze abounded\r\nso, that sky and air seemed vast outbellying sails; the whole world\r\nboomed before the wind. Muffled in the full morning light, the\r\ninvisible sun was only known by the spread intensity of his place;\r\nwhere his bayonet rays moved on in stacks. Emblazonings, as of crowned\r\nBabylonian kings and queens, reigned over everything. The sea was as a\r\ncrucible of molten gold, that bubblingly leaps with light and heat.\r\n\r\nLong maintaining an enchanted silence, Ahab stood apart; and every time\r\nthe tetering ship loweringly pitched down her bowsprit, he turned to\r\neye the bright sun\xe2\x80\x99s rays produced ahead; and when she profoundly\r\nsettled by the stern, he turned behind, and saw the sun\xe2\x80\x99s rearward\r\nplace, and how the same yellow rays were blending with his undeviating\r\nwake.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa, ha, my ship! thou mightest well be taken now for the sea-chariot\r\nof the sun. Ho, ho! all ye nations before my prow, I bring the sun to\r\nye! Yoke on the further billows; hallo! a tandem, I drive the sea!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut suddenly reined back by some counter thought, he hurried towards\r\nthe helm, huskily demanding how the ship was heading.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEast-sou-east, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the frightened steersman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou liest!\xe2\x80\x9d smiting him with his clenched fist. \xe2\x80\x9cHeading East at this\r\nhour in the morning, and the sun astern?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nUpon this every soul was confounded; for the phenomenon just then\r\nobserved by Ahab had unaccountably escaped every one else; but its very\r\nblinding palpableness must have been the cause.\r\n\r\nThrusting his head half way into the binnacle, Ahab caught one glimpse\r\nof the compasses; his uplifted arm slowly fell; for a moment he almost\r\nseemed to stagger. Standing behind him Starbuck looked, and lo! the two\r\ncompasses pointed East, and the Pequod was as infallibly going West.\r\n\r\nBut ere the first wild alarm could get out abroad among the crew, the\r\nold man with a rigid laugh exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cI have it! It has happened\r\nbefore. Mr. Starbuck, last night\xe2\x80\x99s thunder turned our compasses\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nall. Thou hast before now heard of such a thing, I take it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye; but never before has it happened to me, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the pale mate,\r\ngloomily.\r\n\r\nHere, it must needs be said, that accidents like this have in more than\r\none case occurred to ships in violent storms. The magnetic energy, as\r\ndeveloped in the mariner\xe2\x80\x99s needle, is, as all know, essentially one\r\nwith the electricity beheld in heaven; hence it is not to be much\r\nmarvelled at, that such things should be. In instances where the\r\nlightning has actually struck the vessel, so as to smite down some of\r\nthe spars and rigging, the effect upon the needle has at times been\r\nstill more fatal; all its loadstone virtue being annihilated, so that\r\nthe before magnetic steel was of no more use than an old wife\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nknitting needle. But in either case, the needle never again, of itself,\r\nrecovers the original virtue thus marred or lost; and if the binnacle\r\ncompasses be affected, the same fate reaches all the others that may be\r\nin the ship; even were the lowermost one inserted into the kelson.\r\n\r\nDeliberately standing before the binnacle, and eyeing the transpointed\r\ncompasses, the old man, with the sharp of his extended hand, now took\r\nthe precise bearing of the sun, and satisfied that the needles were\r\nexactly inverted, shouted out his orders for the ship\xe2\x80\x99s course to be\r\nchanged accordingly. The yards were hard up; and once more the Pequod\r\nthrust her undaunted bows into the opposing wind, for the supposed fair\r\none had only been juggling her.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, whatever were his own secret thoughts, Starbuck said\r\nnothing, but quietly he issued all requisite orders; while Stubb and\r\nFlask\xe2\x80\x94who in some small degree seemed then to be sharing his\r\nfeelings\xe2\x80\x94likewise unmurmuringly acquiesced. As for the men, though some\r\nof them lowly rumbled, their fear of Ahab was greater than their fear\r\nof Fate. But as ever before, the pagan harpooneers remained almost\r\nwholly unimpressed; or if impressed, it was only with a certain\r\nmagnetism shot into their congenial hearts from inflexible Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\nFor a space the old man walked the deck in rolling reveries. But\r\nchancing to slip with his ivory heel, he saw the crushed copper\r\nsight-tubes of the quadrant he had the day before dashed to the deck.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou poor, proud heaven-gazer and sun\xe2\x80\x99s pilot! yesterday I wrecked\r\nthee, and to-day the compasses would feign have wrecked me. So, so. But\r\nAhab is lord over the level load-stone yet. Mr. Starbuck\xe2\x80\x94a lance\r\nwithout a pole; a top-maul, and the smallest of the sail-maker\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nneedles. Quick!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAccessory, perhaps, to the impulse dictating the thing he was now about\r\nto do, were certain prudential motives, whose object might have been to\r\nrevive the spirits of his crew by a stroke of his subtile skill, in a\r\nmatter so wondrous as that of the inverted compasses. Besides, the old\r\nman well knew that to steer by transpointed needles, though clumsily\r\npracticable, was not a thing to be passed over by superstitious\r\nsailors, without some shudderings and evil portents.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, steadily turning upon the crew, as the mate handed him\r\nthe things he had demanded, \xe2\x80\x9cmy men, the thunder turned old Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nneedles; but out of this bit of steel Ahab can make one of his own,\r\nthat will point as true as any.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAbashed glances of servile wonder were exchanged by the sailors, as\r\nthis was said; and with fascinated eyes they awaited whatever magic\r\nmight follow. But Starbuck looked away.\r\n\r\nWith a blow from the top-maul Ahab knocked off the steel head of the\r\nlance, and then handing to the mate the long iron rod remaining, bade\r\nhim hold it upright, without its touching the deck. Then, with the\r\nmaul, after repeatedly smiting the upper end of this iron rod, he\r\nplaced the blunted needle endwise on the top of it, and less strongly\r\nhammered that, several times, the mate still holding the rod as before.\r\nThen going through some small strange motions with it\xe2\x80\x94whether\r\nindispensable to the magnetizing of the steel, or merely intended to\r\naugment the awe of the crew, is uncertain\xe2\x80\x94he called for linen thread;\r\nand moving to the binnacle, slipped out the two reversed needles there,\r\nand horizontally suspended the sail-needle by its middle, over one of\r\nthe compass-cards. At first, the steel went round and round, quivering\r\nand vibrating at either end; but at last it settled to its place, when\r\nAhab, who had been intently watching for this result, stepped frankly\r\nback from the binnacle, and pointing his stretched arm towards it,\r\nexclaimed,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cLook ye, for yourselves, if Ahab be not the lord of the\r\nlevel loadstone! The sun is East, and that compass swears it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOne after another they peered in, for nothing but their own eyes could\r\npersuade such ignorance as theirs, and one after another they slunk\r\naway.\r\n\r\nIn his fiery eyes of scorn and triumph, you then saw Ahab in all his\r\nfatal pride.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER CXXV. THE LOG AND LINE\r\n\r\n\r\nWhile now the fated Pequod had been so long afloat this voyage, the log\r\nand line had but very seldom been in use. Owing to a confident reliance\r\nupon other means of determining the vessel\xe2\x80\x99s place, some merchantmen,\r\nand many whalemen, especially when cruising, wholly neglect to heave\r\nthe log; though at the same time, and frequently more for form\xe2\x80\x99s sake\r\nthan anything else, regularly putting down upon the customary slate the\r\ncourse steered by the ship, as well as the presumed average rate of\r\nprogression every hour. It had been thus with the Pequod. The wooden\r\nreel and angular log attached hung, long untouched, just beneath the\r\nrailing of the after bulwarks. Rains and spray had damped it; the sun\r\nand wind had warped it; all the elements had combined to rot a thing\r\nthat hung so idly. But heedless of all this, his mood seized Ahab, as\r\nhe happened to glance upon the reel, not many hours after the magnet\r\nscene, and he remembered how his quadrant was no more, and recalled his\r\nfrantic oath about the level log and line. The ship was sailing\r\nplungingly; astern the billows rolled in riots.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForward, there! Heave the log!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTwo seamen came. The golden-hued Tahitian and the grizzly Manxman.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake the reel, one of ye, I\xe2\x80\x99ll heave.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey went towards the extreme stern, on the ship\xe2\x80\x99s lee side, where the\r\ndeck, with the oblique energy of the wind, was now almost dipping into\r\nthe creamy, sidelong-rushing sea.\r\n\r\nThe Manxman took the reel, and holding it high up, by the projecting\r\nhandle-ends of the spindle, round which the spool of line revolved, so\r\nstood with the angular log hanging downwards, till Ahab advanced to\r\nhim.\r\n\r\nAhab stood before him, and was lightly unwinding some thirty or forty\r\nturns to form a preliminary hand-coil to toss overboard, when the old\r\nManxman, who was intently eyeing both him and the line, made bold to\r\nspeak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, I mistrust it; this line looks far gone, long heat and wet have\r\nspoiled it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Twill hold, old gentleman. Long heat and wet, have they spoiled thee?\r\nThou seem\xe2\x80\x99st to hold. Or, truer perhaps, life holds thee; not thou it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hold the spool, sir. But just as my captain says. With these grey\r\nhairs of mine \xe2\x80\x99tis not worth while disputing, \xe2\x80\x99specially with a\r\nsuperior, who\xe2\x80\x99ll ne\xe2\x80\x99er confess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that? There now\xe2\x80\x99s a patched professor in Queen Nature\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngranite-founded College; but methinks he\xe2\x80\x99s too subservient. Where wert\r\nthou born?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the little rocky Isle of Man, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcellent! Thou\xe2\x80\x99st hit the world by that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know not, sir, but I was born there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the Isle of Man, hey? Well, the other way, it\xe2\x80\x99s good. Here\xe2\x80\x99s a man\r\nfrom Man; a man born in once independent Man, and now unmanned of Man;\r\nwhich is sucked in\xe2\x80\x94by what? Up with the reel! The dead, blind wall\r\nbutts all inquiring heads at last. Up with it! So.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe log was heaved. The loose coils rapidly straightened out in a long\r\ndragging line astern, and then, instantly, the reel began to whirl. In\r\nturn, jerkingly raised and lowered by the rolling billows, the towing\r\nresistance of the log caused the old reelman to stagger strangely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold hard!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSnap! the overstrained line sagged down in one long festoon; the\r\ntugging log was gone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI crush the quadrant, the thunder turns the needles, and now the mad\r\nsea parts the log-line. But Ahab can mend all. Haul in here, Tahitian;\r\nreel up, Manxman. And look ye, let the carpenter make another log, and\r\nmend thou the line. See to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere he goes now; to him nothing\xe2\x80\x99s happened; but to me, the skewer\r\nseems loosening out of the middle of the world. Haul in, haul in,\r\nTahitian! These lines run whole, and whirling out: come in broken, and\r\ndragging slow. Ha, Pip? come to help; eh, Pip?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPip? whom call ye Pip? Pip jumped from the whale-boat. Pip\xe2\x80\x99s missing.\r\nLet\xe2\x80\x99s see now if ye haven\xe2\x80\x99t fished him up here, fisherman. It drags\r\nhard; I guess he\xe2\x80\x99s holding on. Jerk him, Tahiti! Jerk him off; we haul\r\nin no cowards here. Ho! there\xe2\x80\x99s his arm just breaking water. A hatchet!\r\na hatchet! cut it off\xe2\x80\x94we haul in no cowards here. Captain Ahab! sir,\r\nsir! here\xe2\x80\x99s Pip, trying to get on board again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace, thou crazy loon,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Manxman, seizing him by the arm.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAway from the quarter-deck!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe greater idiot ever scolds the lesser,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Ahab, advancing.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHands off from that holiness! Where sayest thou Pip was, boy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAstern there, sir, astern! Lo, lo!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who art thou, boy? I see not my reflection in the vacant pupils of\r\nthy eyes. Oh God! that man should be a thing for immortal souls to\r\nsieve through! Who art thou, boy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBell-boy, sir; ship\xe2\x80\x99s-crier; ding, dong, ding! Pip! Pip! Pip! One\r\nhundred pounds of clay reward for Pip; five feet high\xe2\x80\x94looks\r\ncowardly\xe2\x80\x94quickest known by that! Ding, dong, ding! Who\xe2\x80\x99s seen Pip the\r\ncoward?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere can be no hearts above the snow-line. Oh, ye frozen heavens!\r\nlook down here. Ye did beget this luckless child, and have abandoned\r\nhim, ye creative libertines. Here, boy; Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s cabin shall be Pip\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhome henceforth, while Ahab lives. Thou touchest my inmost centre, boy;\r\nthou art tied to me by cords woven of my heart-strings. Come, let\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndown.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s this? here\xe2\x80\x99s velvet shark-skin,\xe2\x80\x9d intently gazing at Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhand, and feeling it. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, now, had poor Pip but felt so kind a thing\r\nas this, perhaps he had ne\xe2\x80\x99er been lost! This seems to me, sir, as a\r\nman-rope; something that weak souls may hold by. Oh, sir, let old Perth\r\nnow come and rivet these two hands together; the black one with the\r\nwhite, for I will not let this go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, boy, nor will I thee, unless I should thereby drag thee to worse\r\nhorrors than are here. Come, then, to my cabin. Lo! ye believers in\r\ngods all goodness, and in man all ill, lo you! see the omniscient gods\r\noblivious of suffering man; and man, though idiotic, and knowing not\r\nwhat he does, yet full of the sweet things of love and gratitude. Come!\r\nI feel prouder leading thee by thy black hand, than though I grasped an\r\nEmperor\xe2\x80\x99s!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere go two daft ones now,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered the old Manxman. \xe2\x80\x9cOne daft with\r\nstrength, the other daft with weakness. But here\xe2\x80\x99s the end of the\r\nrotten line\xe2\x80\x94all dripping, too. Mend it, eh? I think we had best have a\r\nnew line altogether. I\xe2\x80\x99ll see Mr. Stubb about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER CXXVI. THE LIFE-BUOY\r\n\r\n\r\nSteering now south-eastward by Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s levelled steel, and her progress\r\nsolely determined by Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s level log and line; the Pequod held on her\r\npath towards the Equator. Making so long a passage through such\r\nunfrequented waters, descrying no ships, and ere long, sideways\r\nimpelled by unvarying trade winds, over waves monotonously mild; all\r\nthese seemed the strange calm things preluding some riotous and\r\ndesperate scene.\r\n\r\nAt last, when the ship drew near to the outskirts, as it were, of the\r\nEquatorial fishing-ground, and in the deep darkness that goes before\r\nthe dawn, was sailing by a cluster of rocky islets; the watch\xe2\x80\x94then\r\nheaded by Flask\xe2\x80\x94was startled by a cry so plaintively wild and\r\nunearthly\xe2\x80\x94like half-articulated wailings of the ghosts of all Herod\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmurdered Innocents\xe2\x80\x94that one and all, they started from their reveries,\r\nand for the space of some moments stood, or sat, or leaned all\r\ntransfixedly listening, like the carved Roman slave, while that wild\r\ncry remained within hearing. The Christian or civilized part of the\r\ncrew said it was mermaids, and shuddered; but the pagan harpooneers\r\nremained unappalled. Yet the grey Manxman\xe2\x80\x94the oldest mariner of\r\nall\xe2\x80\x94declared that the wild thrilling sounds that were heard, were the\r\nvoices of newly drowned men in the sea.\r\n\r\nBelow in his hammock, Ahab did not hear of this till grey dawn, when he\r\ncame to the deck; it was then recounted to him by Flask, not\r\nunaccompanied with hinted dark meanings. He hollowly laughed, and thus\r\nexplained the wonder.\r\n\r\nThose rocky islands the ship had passed were the resort of great\r\nnumbers of seals, and some young seals that had lost their dams, or\r\nsome dams that had lost their cubs, must have risen nigh the ship and\r\nkept company with her, crying and sobbing with their human sort of\r\nwail. But this only the more affected some of them, because most\r\nmariners cherish a very superstitious feeling about seals, arising not\r\nonly from their peculiar tones when in distress, but also from the\r\nhuman look of their round heads and semi-intelligent faces, seen\r\npeeringly uprising from the water alongside. In the sea, under certain\r\ncircumstances, seals have more than once been mistaken for men.\r\n\r\nBut the bodings of the crew were destined to receive a most plausible\r\nconfirmation in the fate of one of their number that morning. At\r\nsun-rise this man went from his hammock to his mast-head at the fore;\r\nand whether it was that he was not yet half waked from his sleep (for\r\nsailors sometimes go aloft in a transition state), whether it was thus\r\nwith the man, there is now no telling; but, be that as it may, he had\r\nnot been long at his perch, when a cry was heard\xe2\x80\x94a cry and a\r\nrushing\xe2\x80\x94and looking up, they saw a falling phantom in the air; and\r\nlooking down, a little tossed heap of white bubbles in the blue of the\r\nsea.\r\n\r\nThe life-buoy\xe2\x80\x94a long slender cask\xe2\x80\x94was dropped from the stern, where it\r\nalways hung obedient to a cunning spring; but no hand rose to seize it,\r\nand the sun having long beat upon this cask it had shrunken, so that it\r\nslowly filled, and the parched wood also filled at its every pore; and\r\nthe studded iron-bound cask followed the sailor to the bottom, as if to\r\nyield him his pillow, though in sooth but a hard one.\r\n\r\nAnd thus the first man of the Pequod that mounted the mast to look out\r\nfor the White Whale, on the White Whale\xe2\x80\x99s own peculiar ground; that man\r\nwas swallowed up in the deep. But few, perhaps, thought of that at the\r\ntime. Indeed, in some sort, they were not grieved at this event, at\r\nleast as a portent; for they regarded it, not as a foreshadowing of\r\nevil in the future, but as the fulfilment of an evil already presaged.\r\nThey declared that now they knew the reason of those wild shrieks they\r\nhad heard the night before. But again the old Manxman said nay.\r\n\r\nThe lost life-buoy was now to be replaced; Starbuck was directed to see\r\nto it; but as no cask of sufficient lightness could be found, and as in\r\nthe feverish eagerness of what seemed the approaching crisis of the\r\nvoyage, all hands were impatient of any toil but what was directly\r\nconnected with its final end, whatever that might prove to be;\r\ntherefore, they were going to leave the ship\xe2\x80\x99s stern unprovided with a\r\nbuoy, when by certain strange signs and inuendoes Queequeg hinted a\r\nhint concerning his coffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA life-buoy of a coffin!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Starbuck, starting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRather queer, that, I should say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Stubb.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt will make a good enough one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Flask, \xe2\x80\x9cthe carpenter here can\r\narrange it easily.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBring it up; there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing else for it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Starbuck, after a\r\nmelancholy pause. \xe2\x80\x9cRig it, carpenter; do not look at me so\xe2\x80\x94the coffin,\r\nI mean. Dost thou hear me? Rig it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd shall I nail down the lid, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d moving his hand as with a hammer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd shall I caulk the seams, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d moving his hand as with a\r\ncaulking-iron.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd shall I then pay over the same with pitch, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d moving his hand\r\nas with a pitch-pot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAway! What possesses thee to this? Make a life-buoy of the coffin, and\r\nno more.\xe2\x80\x94Mr. Stubb, Mr. Flask, come forward with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe goes off in a huff. The whole he can endure; at the parts he\r\nbaulks. Now I don\xe2\x80\x99t like this. I make a leg for captain Ahab, and he\r\nwears it like a gentleman; but I make a bandbox for Queequeg, and he\r\nwont put his head into it. Are all my pains to go for nothing with that\r\ncoffin? And now I\xe2\x80\x99m ordered to make a life-buoy of it. It\xe2\x80\x99s like\r\nturning an old coat; going to bring the flesh on the other side now. I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t like this cobbling sort of business\xe2\x80\x94I don\xe2\x80\x99t like it at all; it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nundignified; it\xe2\x80\x99s not my place. Let tinkers\xe2\x80\x99 brats do tinkerings; we\r\nare their betters. I like to take in hand none but clean, virgin,\r\nfair-and-square mathematical jobs, something that regularly begins at\r\nthe beginning, and is at the middle when midway, and comes to an end at\r\nthe conclusion; not a cobbler\xe2\x80\x99s job, that\xe2\x80\x99s at an end in the middle,\r\nand at the beginning at the end. It\xe2\x80\x99s the old woman\xe2\x80\x99s tricks to be\r\ngiving cobbling jobs. Lord! what an affection all old women have for\r\ntinkers. I know an old woman of sixty-five who ran away with a\r\nbald-headed young tinker once. And that\xe2\x80\x99s the reason I never would work\r\nfor lonely widow old women ashore, when I kept my job-shop in the\r\nVineyard; they might have taken it into their lonely old heads to run\r\noff with me. But heigh-ho! there are no caps at sea but snow-caps. Let\r\nme see. Nail down the lid; caulk the seams; pay over the same with\r\npitch; batten them down tight, and hang it with the snap-spring over\r\nthe ship\xe2\x80\x99s stern. Were ever such things done before with a coffin? Some\r\nsuperstitious old carpenters, now, would be tied up in the rigging, ere\r\nthey would do the job. But I\xe2\x80\x99m made of knotty Aroostook hemlock; I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t budge. Cruppered with a coffin! Sailing about with a grave-yard\r\ntray! But never mind. We workers in woods make bridal-bedsteads and\r\ncard-tables, as well as coffins and hearses. We work by the month, or\r\nby the job, or by the profit; not for us to ask the why and wherefore\r\nof our work, unless it be too confounded cobbling, and then we stash it\r\nif we can. Hem! I\xe2\x80\x99ll do the job, now, tenderly. I\xe2\x80\x99ll have me\xe2\x80\x94let\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsee\xe2\x80\x94how many in the ship\xe2\x80\x99s company, all told? But I\xe2\x80\x99ve forgotten. Any\r\nway, I\xe2\x80\x99ll have me thirty separate, Turk\xe2\x80\x99s-headed life-lines, each three\r\nfeet long hanging all round to the coffin. Then, if the hull go down,\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99ll be thirty lively fellows all fighting for one coffin, a sight\r\nnot seen very often beneath the sun! Come hammer, calking-iron,\r\npitch-pot, and marling-spike! Let\xe2\x80\x99s to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER CXXVII. THE DECK\r\n\r\n\r\n_The coffin laid upon two line-tubs, between the vice-bench and the\r\nopen hatchway; the Carpenter calking its seams; the string of twisted\r\noakum slowly unwinding from a large roll of it placed in the bosom of\r\nhis frock.\xe2\x80\x94Ahab comes slowly from the cabin-gangway, and hears Pip\r\nfollowing him._\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBack, lad; I will be with ye again presently. He goes! Not this hand\r\ncomplies with my humor more genially than that boy.\xe2\x80\x94Middle aisle of a\r\nchurch! What\xe2\x80\x99s here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLife buoy, sir. Mr. Starbuck\xe2\x80\x99s orders. Oh, look, sir! Beware the\r\nhatchway!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank ye, man. Thy coffin lies handy to the vault.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir? The hatchway? oh! So it does, sir, so it does.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArt not thou the leg-maker? Look, did not this stump come from thy\r\nshop?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe it did, sir; does the ferrule stand, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell enough. But art thou not also the undertaker?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye, sir; I patched up this thing here as a coffin for Queequeg; but\r\nthey\xe2\x80\x99ve set me now to turning it into something else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen tell me; art thou not an arrant, all-grasping, inter-meddling,\r\nmonopolizing, heathenish old scamp, to be one day making legs, and the\r\nnext day coffins to clap them in, and yet again life-buoys out of those\r\nsame coffins? Thou art as unprincipled as the gods, and as much of a\r\njack-of-all-trades.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I do not mean anything, sir. I do as I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe gods again. Hark ye, dost thou not ever sing working about a\r\ncoffin? The Titans, they say, hummed snatches when chipping out the\r\ncraters for volcanoes; and the grave-digger in the play sings, spade in\r\nhand. Dost thou never?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSing, sir? Do I sing? Oh, I\xe2\x80\x99m indifferent enough, sir, for that; but\r\nthe reason why the grave-digger made music must have been because there\r\nwas none in his spade, sir. But the calking mallet is full of it. Hark\r\nto it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye, and that\xe2\x80\x99s because the lid there\xe2\x80\x99s a sounding-board; and what in\r\nall things makes the sounding-board is this\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99s naught beneath. And\r\nyet, a coffin with a body in it rings pretty much the same, Carpenter.\r\nHast thou ever helped carry a bier, and heard the coffin knock against\r\nthe churchyard gate, going in?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFaith, sir, I\xe2\x80\x99ve\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFaith? What\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, faith, sir, it\xe2\x80\x99s only a sort of exclamation-like\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s all,\r\nsir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUm, um; go on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was about to say, sir, that\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArt thou a silk-worm? Dost thou spin thy own shroud out of thyself?\r\nLook at thy bosom! Despatch! and get these traps out of sight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe goes aft. That was sudden, now; but squalls come sudden in hot\r\nlatitudes. I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard that the Isle of Albemarle, one of the\r\nGallipagos, is cut by the Equator right in the middle. Seems to me some\r\nsort of Equator cuts yon old man, too, right in his middle. He\xe2\x80\x99s always\r\nunder the Line\xe2\x80\x94fiery hot, I tell ye! He\xe2\x80\x99s looking this way\xe2\x80\x94come, oakum;\r\nquick. Here we go again. This wooden mallet is the cork, and I\xe2\x80\x99m the\r\nprofessor of musical glasses\xe2\x80\x94tap, tap!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n(_Ahab to himself._)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a sight! There\xe2\x80\x99s sound! The greyheaded woodpecker tapping the\r\nhollow tree! Blind and dumb might well be envied now. See! that thing\r\nrests on two line-tubs, full of tow-lines. A most malicious wag, that\r\nfellow. Rat-tat! So man\xe2\x80\x99s seconds tick! Oh! how immaterial are all\r\nmaterials! What things real are there, but imponderable thoughts? Here\r\nnow\xe2\x80\x99s the very dreaded symbol of grim death, by a mere hap, made the\r\nexpressive sign of the help and hope of most endangered life. A\r\nlife-buoy of a coffin! Does it go further? Can it be that in some\r\nspiritual sense the coffin is, after all, but an immortality-preserver!\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll think of that. But no. So far gone am I in the dark side of earth,\r\nthat its other side, the theoretic bright one, seems but uncertain\r\ntwilight to me. Will ye never have done, Carpenter, with that accursed\r\nsound? I go below; let me not see that thing here when I return again.\r\nNow, then, Pip, we\xe2\x80\x99ll talk this over; I do suck most wondrous\r\nphilosophies from thee! Some unknown conduits from the unknown worlds\r\nmust empty into thee!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER CXXVIII. THE PEQUOD MEETS THE RACHEL\r\n\r\n\r\nNext day, a large ship, the Rachel, was descried, bearing directly down\r\nupon the Pequod, all her spars thickly clustering with men. At the time\r\nthe Pequod was making good speed through the water; but as the\r\nbroad-winged windward stranger shot nigh to her, the boastful sails all\r\nfell together as blank bladders that are burst, and all life fled from\r\nthe smitten hull.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBad news; she brings bad news,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered the old Manxman. But ere her\r\ncommander, who, with trumpet to mouth, stood up in his boat; ere he\r\ncould hopefully hail, Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s voice was heard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHast seen the White Whale?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye, yesterday. Have ye seen a whale-boat adrift?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThrottling his joy, Ahab negatively answered this unexpected question;\r\nand would then have fain boarded the stranger, when the stranger\r\ncaptain himself, having stopped his vessel\xe2\x80\x99s way, was seen descending\r\nher side. A few keen pulls, and his boat-hook soon clinched the\r\nPequod\xe2\x80\x99s main-chains, and he sprang to the deck. Immediately he was\r\nrecognized by Ahab for a Nantucketer he knew. But no formal salutation\r\nwas exchanged.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere was he?\xe2\x80\x94not killed!\xe2\x80\x94not killed!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ahab, closely advancing.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow was it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt seemed that somewhat late on the afternoon of the day previous,\r\nwhile three of the stranger\xe2\x80\x99s boats were engaged with a shoal of\r\nwhales, which had led them some four or five miles from the ship; and\r\nwhile they were yet in swift chase to windward, the white hump and head\r\nof Moby Dick had suddenly loomed up out of the blue water, not very far\r\nto leeward; whereupon, the fourth rigged boat\xe2\x80\x94a reserved one\xe2\x80\x94had been\r\ninstantly lowered in chase. After a keen sail before the wind, this\r\nfourth boat\xe2\x80\x94the swiftest keeled of all\xe2\x80\x94seemed to have succeeded in\r\nfastening\xe2\x80\x94at least, as well as the man at the mast-head could tell\r\nanything about it. In the distance he saw the diminished dotted boat;\r\nand then a swift gleam of bubbling white water; and after that nothing\r\nmore; whence it was concluded that the stricken whale must have\r\nindefinitely run away with his pursuers, as often happens. There was\r\nsome apprehension, but no positive alarm, as yet. The recall signals\r\nwere placed in the rigging; darkness came on; and forced to pick up her\r\nthree far to windward boats\xe2\x80\x94ere going in quest of the fourth one in the\r\nprecisely opposite direction\xe2\x80\x94the ship had not only been necessitated to\r\nleave that boat to its fate till near midnight, but, for the time, to\r\nincrease her distance from it. But the rest of her crew being at last\r\nsafe aboard, she crowded all sail\xe2\x80\x94stunsail on stunsail\xe2\x80\x94after the\r\nmissing boat; kindling a fire in her try-pots for a beacon; and every\r\nother man aloft on the look-out. But though when she had thus sailed a\r\nsufficient distance to gain the presumed place of the absent ones when\r\nlast seen; though she then paused to lower her spare boats to pull all\r\naround her; and not finding anything, had again dashed on; again\r\npaused, and lowered her boats; and though she had thus continued doing\r\ntill day light; yet not the least glimpse of the missing keel had been\r\nseen.\r\n\r\nThe story told, the stranger Captain immediately went on to reveal his\r\nobject in boarding the Pequod. He desired that ship to unite with his\r\nown in the search; by sailing over the sea some four or five miles\r\napart, on parallel lines, and so sweeping a double horizon, as it were.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will wager something now,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Stubb to Flask, \xe2\x80\x9cthat some one\r\nin that missing boat wore off that Captain\xe2\x80\x99s best coat; mayhap, his\r\nwatch\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s so cursed anxious to get it back. Who ever heard of two\r\npious whale-ships cruising after one missing whale-boat in the height\r\nof the whaling season? See, Flask, only see how pale he looks\xe2\x80\x94pale in\r\nthe very buttons of his eyes\xe2\x80\x94look\xe2\x80\x94it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the coat\xe2\x80\x94it must have been\r\nthe\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy boy, my own boy is among them. For God\xe2\x80\x99s sake\xe2\x80\x94I beg, I\r\nconjure\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94here exclaimed the stranger Captain to Ahab, who thus far had\r\nbut icily received his petition. \xe2\x80\x9cFor eight-and-forty hours let me\r\ncharter your ship\xe2\x80\x94I will gladly pay for it, and roundly pay for it\xe2\x80\x94if\r\nthere be no other way\xe2\x80\x94for eight-and-forty hours only\xe2\x80\x94only that\xe2\x80\x94you\r\nmust, oh, you must, and you _shall_ do this thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis son!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Stubb, \xe2\x80\x9coh, it\xe2\x80\x99s his son he\xe2\x80\x99s lost! I take back the\r\ncoat and watch\xe2\x80\x94what says Ahab? We must save that boy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s drowned with the rest on \xe2\x80\x99em, last night,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old Manx\r\nsailor standing behind them; \xe2\x80\x9cI heard; all of ye heard their spirits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNow, as it shortly turned out, what made this incident of the Rachel\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthe more melancholy, was the circumstance, that not only was one of the\r\nCaptain\xe2\x80\x99s sons among the number of the missing boat\xe2\x80\x99s crew; but among\r\nthe number of the other boat\xe2\x80\x99s crews, at the same time, but on the\r\nother hand, separated from the ship during the dark vicissitudes of the\r\nchase, there had been still another son; as that for a time, the\r\nwretched father was plunged to the bottom of the cruellest perplexity;\r\nwhich was only solved for him by his chief mate\xe2\x80\x99s instinctively\r\nadopting the ordinary procedure of a whale-ship in such emergencies,\r\nthat is, when placed between jeopardized but divided boats, always to\r\npick up the majority first. But the captain, for some unknown\r\nconstitutional reason, had refrained from mentioning all this, and not\r\ntill forced to it by Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s iciness did he allude to his one yet\r\nmissing boy; a little lad, but twelve years old, whose father with the\r\nearnest but unmisgiving hardihood of a Nantucketer\xe2\x80\x99s paternal love, had\r\nthus early sought to initiate him in the perils and wonders of a\r\nvocation almost immemorially the destiny of all his race. Nor does it\r\nunfrequently occur, that Nantucket captains will send a son of such\r\ntender age away from them, for a protracted three or four years\xe2\x80\x99 voyage\r\nin some other ship than their own; so that their first knowledge of a\r\nwhaleman\xe2\x80\x99s career shall be unenervated by any chance display of a\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s natural but untimely partiality, or undue apprehensiveness and\r\nconcern.\r\n\r\nMeantime, now the stranger was still beseeching his poor boon of Ahab;\r\nand Ahab still stood like an anvil, receiving every shock, but without\r\nthe least quivering of his own.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not go,\xe2\x80\x9d said the stranger, \xe2\x80\x9ctill you say _aye_ to me. Do to me\r\nas you would have me do to you in the like case. For _you_ too have a\r\nboy, Captain Ahab\xe2\x80\x94though but a child, and nestling safely at home now\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nchild of your old age too\xe2\x80\x94Yes, yes, you relent; I see it\xe2\x80\x94run, run, men,\r\nnow, and stand by to square in the yards.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAvast,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ahab\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ctouch not a rope-yarn;\xe2\x80\x9d then in a voice that\r\nprolongingly moulded every word\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Gardiner, I will not do it.\r\nEven now I lose time. Good bye, good bye. God bless ye, man, and may I\r\nforgive myself, but I must go. Mr. Starbuck, look at the binnacle\r\nwatch, and in three minutes from this present instant warn off all\r\nstrangers: then brace forward again, and let the ship sail as before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurriedly turning, with averted face, he descended into his cabin,\r\nleaving the strange captain transfixed at this unconditional and utter\r\nrejection of his so earnest suit. But starting from his enchantment,\r\nGardiner silently hurried to the side; more fell than stepped into his\r\nboat, and returned to his ship.\r\n\r\nSoon the two ships diverged their wakes; and long as the strange vessel\r\nwas in view, she was seen to yaw hither and thither at every dark spot,\r\nhowever small, on the sea. This way and that her yards were swung\r\nround; starboard and larboard, she continued to tack; now she beat\r\nagainst a head sea; and again it pushed her before it; while all the\r\nwhile, her masts and yards were thickly clustered with men, as three\r\ntall cherry trees, when the boys are cherrying among the boughs.\r\n\r\nBut by her still halting course and winding, woful way, you plainly saw\r\nthat this ship that so wept with spray, still remained without comfort.\r\nShe was Rachel, weeping for her children, because they were not.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER CXXIX. THE CABIN\r\n\r\n\r\n(_Ahab moving to go on deck; Pip catches him by the hand to follow._)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLad, lad, I tell thee thou must not follow Ahab now. The hour is\r\ncoming when Ahab would not scare thee from him, yet would not have thee\r\nby him. There is that in thee, poor lad, which I feel too curing to my\r\nmalady. Like cures like; and for this hunt, my malady becomes my most\r\ndesired health. Do thou abide below here, where they shall serve thee,\r\nas if thou wert the captain. Aye, lad, thou shalt sit here in my own\r\nscrewed chair; another screw to it, thou must be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, no! ye have not a whole body, sir; do ye but use poor me for\r\nyour one lost leg; only tread upon me, sir; I ask no more, so I remain\r\na part of ye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! spite of million villains, this makes me a bigot in the fadeless\r\nfidelity of man!\xe2\x80\x94and a black! and crazy!\xe2\x80\x94but methinks like-cures-like\r\napplies to him too; he grows so sane again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey tell me, sir, that Stubb did once desert poor little Pip, whose\r\ndrowned bones now show white, for all the blackness of his living skin.\r\nBut I will never desert ye, sir, as Stubb did him. Sir, I must go with\r\nye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf thou speakest thus to me much more, Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s purpose keels up in him.\r\nI tell thee no; it cannot be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh good master, master, master!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWeep so, and I will murder thee! have a care, for Ahab too is mad.\r\nListen, and thou wilt often hear my ivory foot upon the deck, and still\r\nknow that I am there. And now I quit thee. Thy hand!\xe2\x80\x94Met! True art\r\nthou, lad, as the circumference to its centre. So: God for ever bless\r\nthee; and if it come to that,\xe2\x80\x94God for ever save thee, let what will\r\nbefall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n(_Ahab goes; Pip steps one step forward._)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere he this instant stood; I stand in his air,\xe2\x80\x94but I\xe2\x80\x99m alone. Now\r\nwere even poor Pip here I could endure it, but he\xe2\x80\x99s missing. Pip! Pip!\r\nDing, dong, ding! Who\xe2\x80\x99s seen Pip? He must be up here; let\xe2\x80\x99s try the\r\ndoor. What? neither lock, nor bolt, nor bar; and yet there\xe2\x80\x99s no opening\r\nit. It must be the spell; he told me to stay here: Aye, and told me\r\nthis screwed chair was mine. Here, then, I\xe2\x80\x99ll seat me, against the\r\ntransom, in the ship\xe2\x80\x99s full middle, all her keel and her three masts\r\nbefore me. Here, our old sailors say, in their black seventy-fours\r\ngreat admirals sometimes sit at table, and lord it over rows of\r\ncaptains and lieutenants. Ha! what\xe2\x80\x99s this? epaulets! epaulets! the\r\nepaulets all come crowding! Pass round the decanters; glad to see ye;\r\nfill up, monsieurs! What an odd feeling, now, when a black boy\xe2\x80\x99s host\r\nto white men with gold lace upon their coats!\xe2\x80\x94Monsieurs, have ye seen\r\none Pip?\xe2\x80\x94a little negro lad, five feet high, hang-dog look, and\r\ncowardly! Jumped from a whale-boat once;\xe2\x80\x94seen him? No! Well then, fill\r\nup again, captains, and let\xe2\x80\x99s drink shame upon all cowards! I name no\r\nnames. Shame upon them! Put one foot upon the table. Shame upon all\r\ncowards.\xe2\x80\x94Hist! above there, I hear ivory\xe2\x80\x94Oh, master, master! I am\r\nindeed down-hearted when you walk over me. But here I\xe2\x80\x99ll stay, though\r\nthis stern strikes rocks; and they bulge through; and oysters come to\r\njoin me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER CXXX. THE HAT\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd now that at the proper time and place, after so long and wide a\r\npreliminary cruise, Ahab,\xe2\x80\x94all other whaling waters swept\xe2\x80\x94seemed to have\r\nchased his foe into an ocean-fold, to slay him the more securely there;\r\nnow, that he found himself hard by the very latitude and longitude\r\nwhere his tormenting wound had been inflicted; now that a vessel had\r\nbeen spoken which on the very day preceding had actually encountered\r\nMoby Dick;\xe2\x80\x94and now that all his successive meetings with various ships\r\ncontrastingly concurred to show the demoniac indifference with which\r\nthe white whale tore his hunters, whether sinning or sinned against;\r\nnow it was that there lurked a something in the old man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, which\r\nit was hardly sufferable for feeble souls to see. As the unsetting\r\npolar star, which through the livelong, arctic, six months\xe2\x80\x99 night\r\nsustains its piercing, steady, central gaze; so Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s purpose now\r\nfixedly gleamed down upon the constant midnight of the gloomy crew. It\r\ndomineered above them so, that all their bodings, doubts, misgivings,\r\nfears, were fain to hide beneath their souls, and not sprout forth a\r\nsingle spear or leaf.\r\n\r\nIn this foreshadowing interval too, all humor, forced or natural,\r\nvanished. Stubb no more strove to raise a smile; Starbuck no more\r\nstrove to check one. Alike, joy and sorrow, hope and fear, seemed\r\nground to finest dust, and powdered, for the time, in the clamped\r\nmortar of Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s iron soul. Like machines, they dumbly moved about the\r\ndeck, ever conscious that the old man\xe2\x80\x99s despot eye was on them.\r\n\r\nBut did you deeply scan him in his more secret confidential hours; when\r\nhe thought no glance but one was on him; then you would have seen that\r\neven as Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s eyes so awed the crew\xe2\x80\x99s, the inscrutable Parsee\xe2\x80\x99s glance\r\nawed his; or somehow, at least, in some wild way, at times affected it.\r\nSuch an added, gliding strangeness began to invest the thin Fedallah\r\nnow; such ceaseless shudderings shook him; that the men looked dubious\r\nat him; half uncertain, as it seemed, whether indeed he were a mortal\r\nsubstance, or else a tremulous shadow cast upon the deck by some unseen\r\nbeing\xe2\x80\x99s body. And that shadow was always hovering there. For not by\r\nnight, even, had Fedallah ever certainly been known to slumber, or go\r\nbelow. He would stand still for hours: but never sat or leaned; his wan\r\nbut wondrous eyes did plainly say\xe2\x80\x94We two watchmen never rest.\r\n\r\nNor, at any time, by night or day could the mariners now step up the\r\ndeck, unless Ahab was before them; either standing in his pivot-hole,\r\nor exactly pacing the planks between two undeviating limits,\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nmain-mast and the mizen; or else they saw him standing in the\r\ncabin-scuttle,\xe2\x80\x94his living foot advanced upon the deck, as if to step;\r\nhis hat slouched heavily over his eyes; so that however motionless he\r\nstood, however the days and nights were added on, that he had not swung\r\nin his hammock; yet hidden beneath that slouching hat, they could never\r\ntell unerringly whether, for all this, his eyes were really closed at\r\ntimes; or whether he was still intently scanning them; no matter,\r\nthough he stood so in the scuttle for a whole hour on the stretch, and\r\nthe unheeded night-damp gathered in beads of dew upon that stone-carved\r\ncoat and hat. The clothes that the night had wet, the next day\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsunshine dried upon him; and so, day after day, and night after night;\r\nhe went no more beneath the planks; whatever he wanted from the cabin\r\nthat thing he sent for.\r\n\r\nHe ate in the same open air; that is, his two only meals,\xe2\x80\x94breakfast and\r\ndinner: supper he never touched; nor reaped his beard; which darkly\r\ngrew all gnarled, as unearthed roots of trees blown over, which still\r\ngrow idly on at naked base, though perished in the upper verdure.
